‘to desire’, pres. I plur. Ⅲ 128.2 āyīmāmane; 3 plur. V 122, 1v1 ātīmāre; participle Bcd 54v2 āyimānai āna, BS anuprārthayamāna-', SuvO. 54r3 ātīmānä, BS -kāmena; pret. 3 plur. K 143, 1057 hvanau ātaudāndä u ysustāṃdī ‘they desired the preaching and approved it’, = BS bhāṣitam abhyanandan, Tib. gzuŋs-pa-la mŋon-par bstod-do', later auda-, Ⅲ 72-166 ātaṃ aude ‘he desired a desire’. Base ā-kam-, to Av. kā-, kāma-, čakana, O.Ind. kāyamāna-, kāma-, kamiṣyate, cakamāna-; beside kan-, see ācastai ‘ you desired ’ above; Waxī kəmī-, kami-: kəmətt, kamat ‘will; agree’, Sanglēčī kəmay-.
‘he may dwell’, Z 2-222 【ka vā vara dāḍaru ā'te' lakṣaṇyo āysäte balysi】‘ if he may dwell there longer, the Buddha adorned with the marks’, to āh- ‘sit, dwell, stay’, with 3 plur. 【ā're】.

‘refraining from’, K 57, 23v3 【ba’ysūñavuysai jsaṃjä jsa ātsāna yaṃdi】 ‘the bodhisattva refrains from killing’, the 【śikṣāpada-】 1 【prāṇātipāta-viratiḥ,】 Pali 【pāṇātipātā veramaṇī】, see BSOAS 13, 1950, 662. Base 【čyā-】, see 【bitsāṃgya】, and 【tsāṣṭa-】.

‘prince’, variant to 【raudäka-】, Ⅲ 39-72 (examples of amorous passion) 【rauste a<bi>ñe pajsi ṣi’ ādrrakä rāma ṣai 28】 ‘prince Rāma even he lost the five magic powers’, = Ⅲ 43.25 【raustaṃ abai’ña pajsa ṣa’ raudäkä rauma ṣe’】 ‘ even prince Rāma lost the five magic powers’. The 【-ka-】 is diminutive suffix, here to【ādrra-】 and 【rauda-:rrund-】‘king’, nom. sing, 【rre】, gen. sing, 【rrundä】. The άπαξ 【 ādrra- 】is from older 【āndra-】, from 【ā】 with the base 【nar-: nr-】 ‘be skilled, able, virile’, hence 【*ānra- › * āndra-】 by the frequent intrusion of the dental stop 【-d- 】between 【-nr-】. The word is formed like Lahndā 【āṇḍrā】, Kalāşa 【ōṇḍrak】 ‘egg’ from 【*ā-nra-ka- 】of the base 【nar-: nr-】 ‘to swell’, in Oss. D.【 närsun,】 I.【närsyn, närst】 ‘to swell’, DI.【nard 】‘fat’ (adj. and noun); Vedic 【āṇḍá-】, later【 aṇḍa-】. See also 【āṃdi’.】
‘being in’, whence ‘from’, Ⅲ 61-53; v 246, 13aI 【ona】, elsewhere 【aunaka】. From the participle 【āna-】 to 【āh-】.
particle after 【cu】, v 5.7.2 【ttye pracaina cu āna;】 v 3.1 【ttye pra<cai>na cu āṃ 】‘because’; v 5.6397, 2.2 【ttye pracaina cu āna】.
Sid. I02v2 read 【ā na】 ‘not’ (【ā = āṃ】), Tib. mi ‘not’.
SVK: This interpretation is contradicted by Bailey’s interpretation of this passage in 【Dict.】 s.v. 【pähad-】, where he has: ‘Sid. 102v2 【vī ā (vīnā?) pyihasti ą̄na padajsāñä】 “without cutting to be burnt”, Tib. mi-bcad-par bsreg-go. ’|||In this part of Si 13.35 the Tibetan has 【hbrum-bu mćhon-gyis bead-la / hphro lcags-kyis bsreg-go // yaṅ-na mi-bcad-par bsreg-go //】 ‘he must cut (【chittvā】) the pustules with a sharp instrument and burn (vahninā sādhayet) the remainder with (a hot) iron. Alternatively, he may burn it without cutting them.’ Thus, it is clear that 【na】 in the Khotanese cannot correspond to Tibetan 【mi】 ‘not’ because 【na padajsāñä】 could only mean ‘it is not to be burned’ whereas the Tibetan has the opposite.|||The passage reads in the Khotanese version: 【ttai mą̄ṇḍaka nauṣṭarą jsa pyįhą̄ñä. u tvā pyihaca hīśinakä jsa padajsą̄ñä. ā vā-v-ī āpyihasti ą̄na *padajsą̄ñä】 (Si 13.35 102v2 【KT】 1.38) ‘those pustules must be cut off (【chittvā】) with a *sharp instrument, and the cut must be burned (【vahninā sādhayet】) with an iron (instrument). Or it must be burned by him while not having been cut.’|||Thus, it is 【āpyihasti ą̄na】 ‘while not having been cut’ which corresponds to Tibetan 【mi-bcad-par】 ‘not having cut’, 【āpyihasti】 may be a miswriting for *【apyihasti】 but it is just possible that 【a-】 has been secondarily lengthened as in 【āhvarai】 ‘sour’ (see 【Dict.】 s.v.). The emenda_x005f_x001f_tion of 【vī ā】 to 【vīnā】 suggested by Bailey would represent a serious change that cannot be supported, vīnā ‘without’ is elsewhere accompanied by a noun or a pronoun not by a past participle. The only occurrence of the word in Si is in A 8 (1 bis r4 【KT】 1.3) 【vinau mātsarä】 ‘without grudging’. [Emmerick, II, p.24 ]

DKS: ‘ reddish (?), v 310, vii r3 【vāra āṃna kabä】 ‘ excellent (?), reddish (?) horse’. If【 āṃna 】is from【 āṃṇa-】, see 【āṃṇaka-】 ‘quail-like bird’ from【 *ā-raxšna-】 to 【rrāṣa- 】‘red’.

‘protected, secure’, V 111, 33rI 【ānatu yanda】, 2 plur. ‘you will protect’, BS 【ārakṣayiṣyatha】*, v 108, 30r5 【ānatä nu yanīyä】, BS 【paripālanam kuryāt】; Ⅲ 128, 29r5-6 【ttäte haṣța gyastaṣṣā ttättu bodhisatvä ānatä yanīndä u haspījīmdī】; Iledong 6, 2a 1 (unpublished)【 ne ānata tcera; later ānam】, Ⅲ 50.42 【karmapaha dasau maista ṣavi haḍā ānaṃ śtāka】 ‘the ten great karmapatha (BS 【karmapatha- 】‘course of action’) must be assured by night and day’; Ⅲ 50.44 【ttarandarä pathaṃka śtāka biśā’ ṣi’ ānaṃ tcere 】‘ restraint of the body is necessary, the tongue is to be secured’. From 【ā-nata-】 to 【nā- :na-】 ‘to protect’, with second component 【nāta-】 (and 【ā】 shortened) or 【nata-】; Tumšuq 【anāḏu】, Kroraina 【anata, anati, anada, anadi, anada lekha, anadi lekha 】with the bases 【rakṣ-】 ‘keep’ and 【dhar-】 ‘hold’, for ‘carefully, sure’, see T. Burrow, The language of the kharoṣțhī documents 73. Base 【nā-】, IE Pok. 754, O.Ind.【 nātha-】 ‘protector’, Greek όνίνημ ‘serve, be useful’. Possibly Sogd. 【”z’t】, if read 【”n’t】 (KT vi 95) ‘exactly’.

‘moistened (?)’, III 84.53 【na-ānahāṃ dvī prūyi maṃgārä gvīha’ rūṃ tcerai】 ‘it (a 【paiṇḍaka】-poultice) must be made without moistening with two 【prūya】-measures of butter (cow oil)’; III 92.237 【u na-ānahā anarva māśa’kä tcerāṃ】, ‘and it (the 【paiṇḍaka-】) must be made with un­moistened unbroken 【māśa’ka】-plant’. Possibly compound (with 【na-】 for【 an-】) to base 【naf- (nap-, nabh-)】 ‘be moist’, Av. 【aiwi-nap-】 ‘pour upon’, 【napta-】 ‘moistened’, Zor.P. 【nam, namb 】‘moist’, 【nambēt, nambītan】 (gloss to Av. 【haēk-】 ‘pour out’), 【naft】, N.Pers. 【nam】 ‘moist’. To IE Pok. 315-16 【enebh-】 ‘moist’, O.Ind. 【nábhas-】 ‘mist, sky’, Av. 【nabah-】, ‘sky’, Greek vέφoς, νεφέλη ‘cloud’, O.Slav. 【nebes-】 ‘sky’, O.Sax. 【neҌal】, O.Engl.【 nifol】 ‘mist’. Hence 【ā-nah-】 ‘to pour upon’, as Av. 【aiwi-nap-】.

‘to be brought’, II 41.9 (SDTV 117)【 parau vā ānāñä】 ‘the command is to be brought’. From 【ā】 with base 【nay-: ny-】, yielding 【ā-na-】 without trace of 【-y-】 (?【 naya- › na-】), see also SuvP. 66v4 【vauñāṃde】, BS 【vāhayantu】; III 38.32 【hañāñāre】 ‘they are made to expand’; Ⅲ 72.162 【nadāṃ】 ‘leaders (?)’; II 104.71 【ganāyai 】‘leader ( ?)’. Base 【nay-】, Av. 【nay-】 with 【ava, upa, para】, Zor.P. 【nītan, ānītan, nayišn】; Sogd. 【nay-】 with 【ā-, fra-, pr”-, ti-】; M.Pers.T. 【nyydn】, pres. 3 sing,【 n‘yd】, participle 【nyyd, riyd】; Yidγa 【vǝnIm: vǝdëm 】‘ bring ’ ‹【 upa-nay-】; Parāčī 【ēn-: ânt】 ‘ to bring ’, 【ūn-: ūnt】 ‘ lead down ’ ‹【 ava-nay-】; Kurd. 【ānīn】. Zaza 【ān-】. IE Pok. 760 Av. 【nayeiti】, O.Ind. 【náyati, nītá-】; Celt. Mid.Irish 【në, nīa 】‘fighter, hero’ ‹ 【*neit-s】, gen. sing 【nīath】; Hittite 【nāi-】 ‘lead’.
- ?-, v 262, DR oIa3 【sa duva ānude haṣṭi brīti】.

‘virility’, II 124.10 【āṃdi’  va<-ṃ ?> ttāparya īḍeṃ (-eṃ = -ai, -e)】 ‘deign to act the man for me’. Assuming 【āṃdi’】 from 【*āṃdra- 】to base 【ā-nar-:ā-nr- 】to nar ‘be virile’ (see also【 ādrraka-】 ‘prince’ from 【*ā-nra-ka-】), as in O.Ind. Vedic 【āṇḍá-】 ‘egg; testicle’【 *ā-nra-】. For lost【 -r-】 from 【-ndr-】, note also 【brya- › bra-, brra-, bryau 】‘more’ 【› byo, brīka › bīka】. The【 -ndr- › -drr-】 in 【ādrraka-】 has kept the 【-r-】, but not the【 -n-】. For 【nar-】 see also s.v. 【naḍe】 ‘man’.
‘disturbance’, Sid. 10rI 【ūysna āphārä】 ‘disturbance of breath’, BS 【śvāsa-】, Tib. 【dbugs mi dbe-ba】; Sid. 6v4 【huña āphārä】. Base 【ā】 with 【phar-】, see pres,【 āphir-: āphida-】.

‘disturbance’, L 89.3-5 【karma vina dukhä vina abe’mañānu vina aysmya āphāranānä harbiśśu jyāre】 ‘the acts 【(karma)】 wholly disappear without woe, without ill- fortune, without disturbances in mind’. See【 āphir-】

‘be disturbed’, Sid. 4rI 【beta vī bure paśä’ u pasālä āphirāre】, BS 【kopaḥ śarad-vasanta-】, Tib. 【rlung-rnams gčog- čing, ston dang dpyid dag dbyar hkhrug-par gyur-te】; V 155, Ia6 【ma thu rāhula aysmū āphirä】 ‘do not, Rāhula, disturb your mind’; Sid. 5r2 【āphirīdä】. Preterite and participle, Sid. 4r3 【āphiḍa】, Sid. 121vI 【āphiḍe】, Tib. 【hkhrugs-te】; Sid. 144vI 【äphaiḍä-】, Ⅲ 84.40 【ṣa’ śya’ had(ā) āpheḍe:】 Ⅲ 131, 2a3 【anāphäḍa-】, Sid. I06r5【 ysaiysai āphīḍe】, Ⅲ 84.44 【ṣi’ ysaiysai āpheḍe 】‘his bile is disturbed’. Causative, Sid. 5r2 【tti maṃ bāta āphirāñāre】 ‘these here excite the wind’, Tib. 【rlung hkhrug-par hgyur-ro】; noun 【āphirāme 】‘disturbance’, Sid. 128v2 【bāti āphirāme jsa】 ‘from disturbance of the wind’, BS 【kopatah】, Tib. rlung hkhrugs-pa-las. See cognates s.v. 【phar-】, pres. 【phir-】.
‘to turn’, Z 24.500 【trāmu ābeistä śśaṃdā samu kho ju cakṛ】 ‘the earth turns like a wheel’. See 【baḍ-】, baltte, causat. 【baiś-】, from *【ā-vṛtsati】.
SGS: *ābei’ls- ‘to turn’ IV a mid. intr. B|||3 sg. pres, mid., O.Kh.: 【ābeistä】 Z 24. 500. [p.9]

DKS: ‘whirlpool’, Z 17.13 【īse yande ku vā ābei’sa natä】 ‘makes whirlpools where are the deep whirling places’; inst. plur. JS 15r2 【ābe’syau khvīyau vyaulasta bajāṣa】 ‘sounds horrific with whirlpools, waves’. See 【ābeistä】 ‘it turns’, without 【ā】 also Z 24.238 【bei’sa】, loc. sing. Z 24.412 【bei’śśa】, older v 40, v5 【klaiśīnā bei’lsa】 ‘waves of affliction’.

‘total’, IV 3.14 l【yiba’ āma】 ‘total’ dyadic, Tib. lib ‘all’; II 63.8 【lyiba’ āma pajīdä】 ‘they demand the total’, without 【āma】 also II 21, 15a6 【lyiba’ pajīdi】. From 【ham-】, 【hāma-】 ‘all’ without 【h-】, beside hama- ‘all’, 【haṃgga-】 ‘total’ from *【hamaka-】, to M.Pers.T. 【hm’g】, 【h’m’g】, 【h’m-】 ‘all’, Zor.P. 【hamāk】, Armen. lw 【hamak】, N.Pers. 【hamah】, Av. 【hama-】. IE Pok. 902-5 【sem】.

‘we may be’, Z 5.107 【ka tä muhu byāta ne āmaṃ】 ‘if we have not been remembered by you’. The older middle ending 【-āmane】, is later frequently 【-āmaṃ】, as IV 3v1 【yanāmaṃ】, IV 3v3 【himāmaṃ】, for older 【yināmane】, 【himāmane】.

‘dwelling-place’, acc. sing. SuvO. 54v4 【ā’mato】, BS 【vihāra-】 v381, 4a4 【ai’metätu】; loc. sing. K 1,134VI 【e’mäta ne biharāre】 ‘they do not dwell in the dwelling (BS 【vihar-】), Tib. 【mi gnas-pa】, V 140, 92v5 【e’mäta】; plural V 116, 65v4 【dripäṣkala ju kṣīre ā’mate】, BS 【trailokya-maṇḍale】; later III 130b2 【śira ā’ma byehūṃ】 ‘ I shall get a good dwelling’ ; Sid. 8r5 【āme】, JS 19r1 【ā’me】. From *【āhāmatā-】 to 【āh-】 ‘sit, dwell’.
‘dwelling’, JS 13v3 【himyai āmunä】 ‘you became a dwelling’, from 【ā】 with 【mān-】 ‘to stay, remain, dwell’. See also 【āmūha-】.

‘short’, contrasting with 【dāra-】 ‘long’, V 299, 2r1 【āmuro jsīno】 ‘short life’ ; V 297, Mac. a, b4 【karma tcamäna hve’ amur<ä> 】‘the act (karma) by which a man <gets> a short <life>’. From 【ā】 with mura- to Av. 【mūra-】 ‘defective’, 【mūraka-】 beside 【dahaka-】. IE Pok. 751—3 【mū-】E5 in Khotan Saka 【muta】 ‘dumb’, O.Ind. 【mū́ka-】, Celtic Ir. 【mut】 ‘short’, Lat. 【mutilus】, 【mūtus】, Greek μυκός, Norw. 【mua】 ‘be silent’.
‘dwelling’, V 286, 7r1 【/// yaṃdi āmuhä】; JS 15v4 【bhāgä āmuhä nāsä】 ‘take portion, dwelling’; III 82.13 【āmūha nāve】 ‘ took the dwelling ’. From 【ā】 with 【mān-】 ‘ to stay ’, see also 【āmunä】.

‘possessing’, II 115.22 【biśau bvaijsyā āmauna】 ‘possessed of all virtues’, parallel to II 115.21 【biśau bvaijsyā haphau】 ‘union with all virtues’. From 【ā】 with 【mauna-】 from 【māna-】, 【mān-】 ‘to stay’. But possibly ‘delightful’, if connected with 【mān-】 ‘delight’, see s.v. 【māja】, to Oss. 【mondag】 ‘desire’.

‘to see’, Sid. 105r5 【cvai hā śīyi śīyi hira āyiṃde u vajsyāte ṣi’ mīḍe】 ‘to whom appear bright white things, and he sees, he will die’, Tib. 【snaŋ-ŋ-čog dkar-por mthoŋ-ba ni hčhi-bar hgyur-ro】; Z 4.100 【samu kho purra āyäte ūca】, Manj. 385 【sa khu pūra āye uca】 ‘just as the moon appears in water’; Z 15.121 【kho ūca banhya āyāre trāmä <. .>】, Manj. 176 【ā khu bahya chāyī uca ṣkaujai āyāre khu byave】 ‘or as a tree’s shadow in water the 【saṃskāra】 factors appear like lightning’; III 29, 41b3 【ni jä nä āyāri hugvāna】, Manj. 263 【nai na ja āyāra hūgvāna】 ‘they do not appear at all’. Verbal noun III 61.52 【ttyāṃ dharma-puṇyāṃ āyāme kiṇa】 ‘to see|||those dharma merits’. Base 【ā-day-】 ‘to see’, Av. 【dai-】: 【di-】, see 【dai-】 ‘see’, also 【vūy-】, 【pūy-】, and 【āya】 ‘official title’.

‘official title, supervisor (?) ’, IV 26.7 【ṣi’ pīḍakä pramāṃda hime khu hā āya haṃguṣṭe vistāte】, ‘this letter becomes valid when the 【āya-】official affixes his finger’, see SDTV 13 ; parallel II 14, 2b8-9 【khuī parramā pyaysīdä】 ‘ when the parramaa- officials sign’. From 【ā-dayā-】 ‘supervisor (?)’, masc. 【ā-】stem, to Av. 【daya-】 in 【paiti.daya-】 ‘overseer’, to 【dai-】 ‘to see’. If the final 【-a】 of 【āya】 stands for older 【-ä】, the base would be 【ā-daya-】.
‘mirror’, Manj. 246 【vasve y(e) āya vīra satv(ā)na āvīda tcīre】 ‘in a clean mirror, one sees the faces of the beings’, parallel to BS 【ādarśa-maṇḍale supariśuddhe】. See 【āyäna-】‘mirror’.

‘it may be’, conjunctive 3 sing, to 【ah-】 ‘be’; 2 sing. Z 2.98 【śśäru tsutai ma stātä āye】 ‘you have well come, do not stand’; 3 plur. Z 4.40 【ku va yakṣa-bhavana ne āro】 ‘where goblin-dwellings do not exist’, BS 【yakṣa-bhavana-】.

‘hilarity’, Z 12.75 【ka bodhisatvä āyiḍetu näjsaṣḍe apracä】, BS 【saṃcagghati saṃkrīḍate saṃkilikīlāyate auddhatyam dravaṃ prāviṣkaroti】 ‘if the bodhisattva shows hilarity without cause’. Base 【kar-】 ‘to play’, see cognates s.v. 【tcarke】, and 【hayär-】.

‘mirror’, Z 24.491 【kye hva’ndi hūdva gva’ haysge patälste ttu mä na vā hvāñita āyärnna cu yīndi】 ‘what man’s two ears, nostrils (=nose) are cut off, you will not tell this to me what he does with a mirror’, =BS Siks. 47.5 【saṃchinna-karṇa-nāsānām ādarśaiṣām kutaḥ priyaḥ】, Tib. 【mi sna daŋ rna-ba bčad-pa-la meloŋ-gi či źig bya】. Loc. sing. Z 4.100 【āyäña】, Z 15.123 【ātīña】, III 52.96 【sa khu āyaña śāma】 ‘like a face in a mirror’, Manj. 283-4 【uce pūra āyañe tcara】 ‘the moon in water, a face in a mirror’; Manj. 300 【khu āyīñai dyāma tcīre】 ‘like the sight of a face in a mirror ’; Manj. 373 【ā tcīra āyeña dette】 ‘as a face is seen in a mirror’. This is a cliché, as Mahāyāna-sūtrālaṃkāra 11.30 【udaka-candra-bimba-sadṛśāḥ】 and Śikṣ. 261.18 【ādarśa-maṇḍale】. Without final -a- III 70.105 【āyeṃ baña】 ‘bind on a mirror’ (Rāma’s advice to the monkey); K 28.181-2 【khu ja āye spāśa】 ‘as a mirror appears’, =K 21.6-7. From *【ādaina-】 or *【ādayana-】; Sogd. 【’’δ’yn’k】, M.Parth.T. 【”dyng】, Zor.P. 【aδvēnak】, N.Pers. 【āēnah】, Balōčī 【ādēnk】, Oss. D. 【ajdänä】, I. 【ajdän】, to 【ā】 with 【dai-】: 【di-】 ‘to see’.

‘example, simile’, Z 19.89 【āyänai】. Z 19.86 【āyīnai】, Z 19.91 【āyīnau】, III 74.201 【āyanā vāśā’ṃdä yāṃdä】 ‘they continually recited examples’, =BS 【dṛṣṭānta】, found in III 29, 44b2 【diṣṭānta】. From *【ā-dayanaka-】, see also 【āyäna-】‘mirror’, to base 【dai-】 ‘to see’.

‘ground, sole of foot’, SuvO. 56r1 【ttere jsa ttye dāta-hvāñei pānu ā’ye<. .>nīmä】 ‘with forehead I embrace the soles of the feet of this dharma-preacher ’, BS 【uttamāngena ca tasya dharma-bhāṇakasya bhikṣoḥ pāda-talau pratisaṃhariṣyāmi】; SuvO. 56r3 【odä vaśiriṃgye śśaṃdye ā’ye, BS yāvad vajramayaṃ pṛthivī-talam upādāya】 ‘as far as the ground of the adamantine earth’. See also 【eväte】 ‘street’, and 【aya】 ‘ground’. From 【āy-】 (the hook indicating older 【āyy-】), with Av. 【āi】, and N.Pers. 【xāk】 ‘dust’. M.Parth.T. 【’y’g】 ‘place’ may be added here. For N.Pers. 【xāk】 a derivation from *【āhaka-】 ‘ashes’ is proposed by G. Morgenstierne, NTS 12, 1942, 266, with 【Parāčī hāγ】.

K 156·17 for *【āyaunye】 written possibly 【āyaunnye】, lw from BS 【āyāneya-, ājāneya-】 ‘well-born’, III 64·20 【āyānye bvaiysye jsīna】 (with 【n】, not 【ñ】) 【paba】, K 156·17 【ttravargye āyau*nye jsīña paba】, II 103·52 【bvaiysyai ttravargyai jsīña paba】 ‘three-divisioned well-born life continuum’. The adjective is also in JS 27V1 【aśe yai āyānī rruṃde subhadrre】 ‘you were the horse well-born of king Subhadra’. BS 【ājāneya-, āyāneya-】, Pali 【ājānīya-, ājāniya-, ājañña-】, and compound 【assājāniya-】, see JRAS 1955, 14. For 【-tty-】 replacing 【-ny-】 see V 64·43 【ṣamattyau】.

SVK: In Bailey’s translation of P 3513 #82r3-4 【KBT】65 【baiśa ysaṃtha daha ysyāne āysā krraña】 in 【Dict.】 20b the substantive 【daha】 ‘male’ has been accidentally left untranslated. Preferable is his translation in ‘The profession of prince Tcūin-ttehi’, in 【Indological studies in honor of W. Norman Brown】, New Haven 1962, 21: ‘May I be bom in every birth a man, well-born, showing gratitude’.|||[Maggi, III, p. 23]

SVK: Khotanese 【īra-】 corresponds both to Buddhist Sanskrit 【śilā】 and 【vajra】 as pointed out by Bailey. If the meaning was ‘diamond’ there is no discrepancy since 【śilā】 simply meant a hard stone. T. Burrow pointed out in 【The Adyar Library Bulletin】, 44—45, 1982, 444—445 that Sanskrit 【hīra-】 means ‘diamond’ and that 【hīra-】 could be an Iranian loanword. He suggested that it may have been borrowed from a Saka dialect that had a prothetic 【h】 in this word.|||The main river of Khotan is known as the Qara Qaš ‘Black Jade (River)’, a Turkish designation of the river that accords with the Chinese designation Wu-yü-ho (Black Jade River), which is known from the tenth century. The river is known in Sanskrit as 【Śailodā】 and in the Tibetan Annals of Khotan as 【śel-chu】 or 【śel-chab】 ‘jade river’. These matters were discussed in detail by G. Uray in 【Prolegomena to the sources on the history of pre-Islamic Central Asia】, ed. J. Harmatta, Budapest 1979, 290—294.|||Tibetan 【śel】 meant simply a valuable hard stone and so could be applied to jade just as well as to diamonds. It is no doubt a loanword from Skt 【śilā】, although B.Laufer was uncertain (【TP】, 1916, 465).|||Skt 【hīra(ka)】 meant ‘diamond’. It was explained as 【vajra-paryāya-nāma】 by Hemacandra, Abhidhana-cintāmaṇi 4.161. It is included as one of the fourteen names of the diamond in the Rājanighaṇṭu (R. Garbe, 【Die indischen Mineralien】, Leipzig 1882, p. 80). In Mvy 5950 【hīra(ka)】 is glossed by Tibetan 【pha-lam】 whereas in Mvy 5951 【vajra】 is glossed by Tibetan 【rdo-rje】, but the Chinese has 金剛【chin kang】 (Mathews 1057 + 3268) for both 【hīraka】 and 【vajra】. The Chinese is short for 金剛石 【chin|||kang shih】 (+ Mathews 5813), which really means ‘precious hard stone’. Tibetan 【pha-lam】 is explained by Jäschke as ‘diamond’, which accords with Sumatiratna’s gloss by Mongolian 【almas】 ‘diamond’. The latter word is well known in Iranian (Persian 【almās】): see e.g. Bailey’s discussion of Pahlavi 【’lm’s(t’)】 in his 【Zoroastrian problems in the ninth-century books】, Oxford 1943 (repr. 1971), p. 134. The word is known in Russian 【almáz】 ‘diamond’ and elsewhere: see M.Vasmer, 【Russisches etymologisches Wörterbuch】, vol. 1, Heidelberg 1953 s.v. Tibetan 【pha-lam】 is explained by Chos-kyi grags-pa, 【Brda-dag miṅ-ćhig gsal-ba】, Peking 1957, as 【śel-rigs nor-buhi mchog】 ‘an excellent precious kind of 【śel】’.|||The above evidence makes it likely that Khotanese 【īra-】 meant precious hard stone like Sanskrit 【śilā】 and Tibetan 【śel】. It could be applied to jade, the hard stone par excellence in Khotan, or to the diamond. Sanskrit 【hīra(ka)】 meant ‘diamond’ and may have been borrowed from Khotanese 【īra-】.|||The adjective 【īrīnaa-】 with the common adjective suffix 【-īnaa-】 is attested in Khotanese in 【īrīnā gari】 ‘the jade mountains’ (N 158.5). With a different suffix like the Khotanese adjective suffix 【-āña-】 the word is found in Tumshuqese 【xšere irāñye】 ‘of the jade land’ (= Khotanese 【*kṣīri īrīnai】) in S. Konow, 【Ein neuer Saka-Dialekt】, Berlin 1935, p. 41 (V. 2).[Emmerick, Ⅱ, p.29]

SVK: The stem is 【uysanā-】, not 【uysana-】 as revealed by the OKh. instr.-abl. sg. 【uysäñe jsa】 with 【-ä-】 due to trisyllabic weakening and with palatalisation of 【-n-】 > 【-ñ-】 caused by the unambiguous 【ā-】declension instr.-abl. sg. ending 【-《i》e jsa】.|||To 【uysäñe jsa】 Bailey devotes a separate entry proposing the meaning ‘in one moment (?)’. The semantic development ‘in one breath’ > ‘in one moment’ is quite plausible, but a glance at the wider context where 【uysäñe jsa】 occurs suffices to show that it is to be understood in its literal meaning with E. Leumann, N 51 (‘Aushauchung, Pusten’): N 50.22-25 【pātcu kāśyapa ko ju hve’ panamäta ce ttrāmo hoto näjsaṣḍe ku sumīru garu nāste nänerra tcabaljätä pärāñätä uysvāñätä o vā śiñe uysäñe jsa handarña lovadhato bīräta tta cu tä saittä kāśyava duṣkaru ṣä hve’ ttu kīru yīndä】 ‘Then, Kāśyapa, if a man should rise, who shows such strength that he would take Mount Sumeru in the palm of (his) hand, break up, scatter (and) throw (it) up, or (that) he would throw (it) into another world by one breath, thus - what does it seem to you, Kāśyapa - (is it) extraordinary (if) that man does that deed?’. I see no reason for regarding this passage as ‘parallel to K 60, 36v4 【ttī hamye kṣaṇa uysānā ba’ysą dittä】 “then at the same moment the self sees the Buddha”’ occurring in a wholly different context. [Maggi, Ⅲ, p.28]

SVK: Both 【ysīcaurga】 and 【ysīḍaurga】 are rendered ‘very yellow’ by Bailey (s. vv. 【ysīcaurga】 and 【ysīḍai】 respectively) whereas he renders 【śīyaurga】 as ‘white’ and 【haryāsaurga】 as ‘black’ (s. vv. 【śīyaurga】 and 【haryāsa-】 respectively). No reason for this discrepancy is given and no evidence is given for the meaning ‘very’. It looks, however, as though Bailey based the meaning ‘very’ on Si 24.19 (140r4 【KT】 1.78) since s. v. 【ysīḍai】 he writes ‘Sid. 140r4 【ysīḍaurgä hame】 “becomes very yellow”, Tib. 【ser che-la’】. However, 【ser che】 does not mean ‘very yellow’ even though the Khotanese translator appears to have misunderstood 【ser】 as ‘yellow’. 【ser】 is here the equivalent of 【bser】 ‘cold wind’. The Tibetan has 【dus thams-cad-du graṅ-źiṅ ser che-la skam-du mi-btub-pahi sar】 ‘in a place (【deśe】) which is cold (【śītale】) at all times (【sarvatra】), where there is much cold wind, and where one cannot keep dry (= 【sthirodake】)’. 【ser che-la】 ‘where there is much cold wind’ is thus an elaboration of the foregoing. The Sanskrit does not mention yellowness and it is not expected in the context. The Khotanese rendering is based on a misinterpretation of the Tibetan and cannot be used to prove that 【ysīḍaurgä】 means ‘very yellow’, for which 【śin-tu ser-po】 would be expected in Tibetan.|||In Si 22.4 (133v5-134rl 【KT】 1.68) and 23.8 (136v3 【KT】 1.72) 【śīyaurga】 corresponds to Tibetan 【skya】. The former passage does not occur in the Sanskrit but at 23.8 the Sanskrit has 【pāṇḍu-pīta】. The Sanskrit 【pāṇḍu-pīta】 was taken as a single item by the Tibetan translators, who were followed by the Khotanese. The Tibetan 【skya】 regularly corresponds to Sanskrit 【pāṇḍu】 alone and like it means, according to Jäschke, ‘whitish gray, yellowish-white’. It will be no chance that the Tibetan has 【skya】 rather than 【dkar-ba】 ‘white’. In any case it is clear that 【skya】 is not ‘very white’.|||In Si 24.4 (138v2 【KT】 1.76) it is not 【śīyaurga】 that corresponds to Tibetan 【skya】  and Sanskrit 【pāṇḍu】 but 【ysīcaurga】 from 【ysīca】 ‘yellow’.|||It is possible to account for the use of both 【śīyaurga】 and 【ysīcaurga】 to render Tibetan 【skya】 ‘yellowish white’ only if we assume that 【-aurga】 has a modifying and not an intensifying effect. In other words, 【śīyaurga】 must mean ‘whitish’ and 【ysīcaurga】 ‘yellowish’ rather than ‘very white’ and ‘very yellow’.|||In Si 14.4 (105r3 【KT】 1.42), however, 【śīyaurga】 ‘whitish’ does correspond toTibetan 【dkar】 ‘white’ and not to 【skya】 ‘yellowish white’. The Sanskrit has 【śvetābhaṃ】 and not ‘BS 【pīta-】’ as Bailey, Dict. s. v. 【śīyaurga】. It looks as though the Khotanese translator has taken 【śvetābhaṃ】 to mean ‘having a white appearance’ and therefore ‘whitish’ rather than ‘white’. Similarly, 【kṛṣṇābho】 in Si 14.2 is rendered by 【haryāsaurga】 ‘blackish’ (105rl 【KT】 1.42) and not by 【haryāsa】 ‘black’.|||【-aurga】 may derive from 【*-a-varna-ka-】 ‘having something of the colour of’ with 【*varna-】 ‘colour’ (cf. Old Indian 【várṇa-】 ‘colour’).[Emmerick, I, p.28][Skjærvø , Ⅲ, p.37]

SVK: No evidence is given in the 【Dict】, for the meaning ‘circle’ and the evidence of Si 26.7 points to the meaning ‘line’. Bailey quotes part of Si 26.7 with the corresponding Tibetan, which he claims is ‘different’ but which he does not translate. In fact, the Khotanese and the Tibetan agree quite closely.||| [Ⅱ,p.32]

‘secretary’ (?) [cf. ka’rä ‘title’, Diet. 53-54]|||In 【SDTV】 1.4 Bailey renders this word as ‘offer’ in the combination 【ka ’rä varāysai】 ‘the offer of the gratuity,’ but in Dict. 53-54 he suggested "ka'rä-official,’ which is certainly correct. The expression 【ka'rä N.N.】 in the I.O.L. and Urumqi wood tablets (see Skjærvø, ‘Kings of Khotan’, pp. 273, 276) clearly contains the title and name of the scribe. Thus, ka’ra- is probably from *ka -《1》 + -(k)ara-, with the ka ’-, a kind of art or skill, which Emmerick {Studies 2.34-35; see the passages discussed there} derived from OIr. *【kaiša-】 (Av. 【tkaēša-】, etc.; see also on 【kṣī】 below). The particu­lar skill required here is apparently that of official scribe or secretary, obviously an important position.|||Such a meaning would also fit Z 24《241》 iṣvastu cakr̥̣ṇa . kau ’ rraukyo haṃkhīysgyo ‘arrow-shooting, discus, *writing, reckoning, counting,’ where kau ’, rather than being instruction in discus throwing, is one of the secretarial arts like reckoning and counting (i.e., calculation, algebra). We may compare 【Suv】 [16.12], Skt. text, 175.6-7: 【lipi-samkhyā-gananā-su- śiksito babhūva】, for which only the third item is preserved in the Khot. translation (Leumann, 【N.】, *99vl) 【[... ṣu]murjo《1》 ve husīyu *väte】 ‘He was well learned in [writing, reckoning, and] *counting.’|||In the Rāma story, it would no doubt be in the prince’s interest to have writing skills in order to serve the brahmins, and the texts in Ch 0050a, b are a student’s writing exercises or drafts of letters.|||In the 【Sudhanāvadāna】, 【ke'】 may have taken on the concrete meaning of ‘written (letter).’|||[Skjærvø, Ⅲ, p.39]|||I do not consider that Skjservo has proved that 【ka'-】 means ‘writing’ rather than, more generally, ‘instruction’, even though the instruction may sometimes have included instruction in the art of writing. I doubt very much whether Naṇḍa the monkey in the Rāma story learnt to write rather than received general instruction. Skjærvø translates cakr̥ṇa kau' in Z24《241》 simply as ‘discus, *writing’, but cakrna is instr.-abl. sg., which is why in 【Studies】 2.35 I suggested it meant ‘instruction in connection with the discus’. Moreover, if we follow Skjservo in seeing 【ka-】 in 【ka’ra-】, it actually provides a better interpretation if we assume the meaning ‘instruction’ for 【ka-】as the 【ka'ra-】 will then be an ‘instructor’, which accords very well with the word 【varāysai】 that accompanies 【ka'rä】 in Hedin 44 and 45 and which Skjærvø renders ‘director’ s.v.【 harays-】 below. Whether what was given in the 【Sudhanāvadāna】 was an oral message or a written one as Skjærvø suggests, there is no means of knowing.|||On the Khotanese word for ‘to write’ see on 【pīr-】 below.|||[Emmerick，Ⅲ, p.39]

B., 【AM】, N.S., ii. I, 1951, 25).|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【krriye】 P 2801. 45 【KT】 3. 67; O.Kh. ppp. in 【akrīya-】Z 13.114 ‘unstruck’.|||Et. Iter. < 【*kark-】, v. 【kaljs-】.[p.21]

SGS: meaning: see below. V b mid. intr. B ppp. kaṣṭa-|||3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【kaśtä】 Z 22. 320; 24. 451; 【kaśte】 Z 2. 111, 118; 10. 12; Ⅱ. 27; 24. 504.|||3 pl. pres, mid., O.Kh.: 【kaśśāre】 Z 10. Ⅱ; Ⅱ. 17, 31, 33, 47.|||ppp. 【akaṣṭa】 P 3513. 48v2-3 【KT】 1. 225 【tr. asakta-. kaṣṭe】 Z 24. 178 could be 3 sg. pf. tr. m. ‘attached’; kaṣṭa Z 23. 36. 3 sg. pf. intr. f. ‘was attached’. But 【ttye vī kaṣṭa】 P 2025. 156 【KBT】 16 = 【ttya vī kaṣṭa】 Ch 00266. 97 【KBT】 24 = 【ttye vī ā 】2957. 49 【KBT】 33.|||Et. 【kaśś-】 ‹ *【kas-ya-】, cf. 【ātas-】. That 【kas-】 is inch. ‹ *【kaf-】 as implied by H. W. B., 【TPS】, 1945, 30 seems unlikely as *【kafs-】 should result in *【kaus-】 like 【ttaus-】 ‹ *【tafs-】. The statement that 【kaśś-】 is ‘inchoa¬tive of 【kas-】 ‹ *【kaf-s-】’ (Dresden, p. 471 s.v. 【kaś-】) is meaningless to me. Three verbs may be hidden here according to H. W. B., 【AM】, N.S. ii. 1, 1951, 31:|||1. 【kaśte】 ‘falls’ Ch 00268. 47 【KBT】 103 etc., cf. Oss. D. 【xaun】; Parth. 【kf-, kft】.|||2. 【kasta-】 ‘attached’ with *【kaz-】, cf. Arm. LW 【kazm】 ‘order, ornament’ (H. W. B., 【AM】, N.S. i, 1949, 45).|||3. 【kaśte】 ‘appears’ Z 2. 118 ‹ *【kas-】, cf. Oss. D. 【käsun】 ‘appear’. 【kaṣṭa-】 ‘attached’ could, however, be from a base *【kas-】 and this has been found in Oss. D.【 nixäsun】 ‘to cling’ (H. W. B., 【JRAS】, 1961, 54; 【KT】 4. 90). Unless this is really ‘fall down upon’, we still lack an etymology for *【kas-】 ‘fall’. In further support of a base *【kaz-】, H. W. B. has given me Sogd. h'z'kh ‘hut’, cf. NP 【kāz】 ‘den of wild beasts’, 【kāzah】 ‘house’ (W. B. Henning, 【TPS】, 1945, 158, n.3)
‘to fall’ (?) act. intr. A/B|||3 pl. pres, act., O.Kh.: 【kasīndä】 Kha 0013c6. b3 【KT】 5. 125.|||Et. Cf. 【ātas-】,【 kaśś-】[p.22]

‘a title’, v 33, 12a5 【pirām kāla himye】 ‘he became the 【hāla】-official of the houses(?)’, see s.v. 【päravārā】. With the title 【ūtci】, v 187, 62a1-2 【ūtca-hāle kālä】, ibid, 【ūtca-hālai kālä】, ibid, 【ūtca-hāle kālä】 after proper names.

SVK: In this entry Bailey quotes SuvO. 27v7 KT 1.236 [Suv 61.11] 【‘kāṣṭānu vadravānu】 (BS 【upadrava-】) 【näṣemākä】 “calmer of grievous troubles”, BS 【śokāyāsa-praśamana-】’. He does not explain how 【kāṣṭa-】 ‘thought; cared for’, a past participle passive, came to mean ‘grievous’. As a matter of fact, instead of 【kāṣṭänu】 we must read with the MS 【kāscanu】 ‘griefs’, 【kāṣcā-】 translates 【śoka-】 here as in all its other occurrences in Suv and three times in Sgh.|||[Skjærvø, I, p.32]

DKS: ‘hemp’, see kaṃha-,Ⅳ47a1 and b1 kāhyene;51b1 kāhye-
‘drops’，gen. plur., K 41.86 【ūci hīya kināṃ haṃkhīysä】 ‘the number of drops of water’, =K 44.203 【ūci hīyāṃ kinā haṃkhīysi】. See 【kanā-】 ‘drop’.

SVK: On this non-existent word see on arkakä above.[Ⅰ，p.32]

Bailey quotes 【kälstä väta】, Skt 【avaropita-】 from SuvO. 5v3 【KT】 1.234 [Suv 2.2] but does not indicate how 【kälstä väta】 is to be analysed. The compound tenses of the Khotanese verb have unfortunately never been discussed, 【SGS】 treating only simple tenses; however, they are very common and a few examples suffice to show how they are used. Past tense forms with the auxiliary 【väta-】 (pluperfect) are active or passive:|||Active: SuvO. 5v4 [Suv 2.2] 【ce pajsamu yäde vätā】 ‘who had done honour’ (3 sg. m. trans.); [Suv 15.50] 【[byau]dāndä väta】 ‘they had ob_x005f_x005f_x005f_x001f_tained, Skt 【pratilabdhä babhūvuh】 (3 pl. m. trans.); [Suv 17.159] 【byūsta väta】 ‘(night) had turned into dawn’ (3 sg. f. intr.); [Suv 15.51] 【hämäte väte】‘they had become’ (3 pl. f. intr.).|||Passive: [Suv 16.46] 【*ci ... *āchyau skuta väta】 ‘who had been touched by illnesses’ (3 pl. m.).|||We see that the active pluperfect is obtained by adding the proper forms of väta- to the simple perfect:【yäde】 ‘he did’ — 【yäde vätä/e 】‘he had done’, hämäte ‘they (f.) became’ — 【hämäte väte】 ‘they had become’. In the passive pluperfect we have an ordinary passive construction, the participle and the auxiliary both agreeing with the grammatical subject.|||So we see that 【kälstä väta】 can be neither active ‘he had planted’ 【(kälste vätä/e)】 nor passive ‘they had been planted’【(kälstä väta (m.), kälste väte (f.))】. The Suv passage runs as follows: 【sā ... vätä yäda- vajsamä. kälstä väta ááärye härä bāta】, Skt 【°krtädhikāro ’varopita-kuáala- mūlo】. The Khotanese ought to mean ‘he was one who had done honour (to previous Buddhas); he had planted the roots of merit’. Since 【bāta】 is nominative singular one might assume that 【kälstä väta】 is simply a lapsus for 【kälstä väta】. However, the problem is resolved by inspection of the manuscript. Indeed, the correct reading is not 【kälstä】, but 【kälstai】, and 【kälstai väta】 means ‘by him had been sown’, 【kälstai】 being from 【kälstä】 + i, enclitic personal pronoun 3 sg. Thus there is no grammatical irregularity in the text. [Skjsærvø, I, p.32]

The plant name 【kulīrai】 occurs twice in the Si to translate Sanskrit 【arjaka 】‘shrubby basil’ (Ocimum gratissimum Linn.): Si 2.24 (13v3 KT 1.20) and 22.11 (134vl 【KT】 1.68).|||Bailey’s 【Dict】. leaves the ‘connexions unknown’. A glance at SiN 107 suffices to show that 【kulīrai】 represents Sanskrit 【kuṭheraka】, which is there given as a synonym of 【arjaka】.|||See 【Die Sprache】, 29, 1983.[Skjsærvø, I, p.32]

N. Sims-Williams suggests that the Khotanese word is related to Buddhist Sogdian kwč'kh, Man. and Chr. qwč' ‘mouth’, which he derives from *kauždačī- + -ā-kä (【BSOAS】, XLVI.l, 1983, 47). [Emmerick, II, p.34]
see kau’

DKS: read sqikai *sam in K 39*147, ‘this for him’, = K 30-217 sqika.
a particular art taught to a young prince, mentioned after cakrna ‘with discus weapon ’
SVK: 【a particular art taught to a young prince (Diet.) 】 Z 24.241 has:|||【huṣṣātä rraysgu harbiśśe sīye ṣṣahāne|||iṣvastu cakṛṇa. kau' rraukyo haṃkhīysgyo,】|||which I rendered: ‘He grew up quickly. He learned all the virtues, arrow_x001F_shooting, discus-throwing, reckoning, counting.’ This rendering was based on conjectures made by Bailey concerning the words 【kau’】 and 【rraukyo】: see 【KT】 6.53, 313. In 【KT】 6.53 Bailey suggested that 【cakṛṇa kau’】 may mean ‘casting the discus’ like Pali 【cakka-viddha-】. In the 【Dict】, he rather improbably takes 【cakṛṇa kau’】 as two items ‘discus-throwing, slinging’, thus disregarding the instr.-abl. ending of 【cakṛṇa】.|||In the Khotanese Rāma story Narnia the monkey says: 【vilakä ṣṭāṃ sīyeṃ ka’brraṃmanāṃ pārśa’ yuḍeṃ】 (Rāma 141 【KT】 3.71), which Bailey translated: ‘While still young I learnt to think, I served the Brahmans’ (BSOAS, X.3,1941,567). In 【Dict.】 s.v. 【ka’】 he quotes 【vilakä ṣṭāṃ sīyeṃ ka’】 and renders it ‘when young I learned to think’. There he refers to N 176.5—6 【ci ke’ sājīndä ggaraṇi-śāstra ci vātcu śākhe sājīndä】, which he renders ‘some learn to think (= study) of the treatises of action (of the calendar?), some next learn the branches (BS 【śākhā-】 sectarian text?)’. Leumann had understood 【ke’】 as coordinated with 【ggaraṇi-śāstra-】. ‘die Prüfsteine ... (und) die Karaṇa-Lehrbücher’. His interpretation of 【ke’】 as ‘Prüfsteine’ is presumably based on the assumption that it represents Sanskrit 【kaṣa】 ‘touchstone’. The interpretation of 【ke’】 as an infinitive meaning ‘to think’ goes back to S. Konow, 【Saka Studies】, Oslo 1932, p. 150 s.v. 【kāṣ】. This interpretation is formally possible but it does not yield acceptable sense and 【sāj-】 ‘to learn’ is not otherwise construed with an infinitive.|||It is also unlikely that the pupils are being ordered to think in the documents Ch 0050 a and Ch 0050 b in 【KT】 1—3 ed.2 pp. 144—145, where we read (Ch 0050 b 2.2): 【parau hamye sa ka’ sājara】 ‘there was the order: “learn 【ka’】 ”. The fact that 【sajara】 is written in Ch 0050a.6 and Ch 0050 b 1.3 instead of 【sājara】 should not discourage us from understanding this as sājara ‘learn’ as the repetitions show that the sentence is being practised by an unskilled scribe.|||It is possible that the pupils are being ordered to learn ‘throwing’ but also not very likely. In the context it is also unlikely that the monkey Naṇḍa should have learned the art of throwing. Something more general seems to be required but something that could be associated with the discus as part of a royal education. This more general item is likely to be that found in Sudh A 69 KBT 34:【pyari gyastä vīrāṣṭä ke’ hūḍi ysīrasthi】, which Bailey, 【Dict. s.v. ke’】 ‘message’, renders ‘to his father the 【deva-】king he gave a heart-felt message’. Bailey proposes to explain 【ke’】 as from 【*kaiša-】, which he connects with Avestan 【t̠kaēša-】. This etymology is formally without difficulty and provides the meaning required for all the passages under discussion. Avestan 【t̠kaëša- 】means ‘teaching, instruction’, which would very well suit what the monkey Naṇḍa learned when he served the brahmins and the prince would have needed instruction in connection with the discus.|||Old Khotanese 【kau’】 is probably contracted from 【*kätu’】 for which cf. 【bätu’】, acc. sg. ‹ 【*viša-】 ‘poison’. The Late Khotanese forms will reflect the old nom. 【*kei’】, cf. LKh. 【ba’】, 【be’】 ‘poison’ for OKh. 【bei’】.[Emmertick, II, p.34]

Bailey derives LKh. 【kauvāle】 ‘from 【kaub-】 “to practise rites, pray”’ + 【*varda-ka-】 ‘practiser’. The difficulties of deriving Kh. 【°vālaa-】 from OIr. 【*vardaka-】 are already apparent from Bailey’s arguments, so that his etymology is no more convincing than his earlier one in BSOAS., XXIX.3, 1966, 520-521 (from Pkt. ‘*【kāvva-vālaga-】, keeper of the 【kāvva-】, with 【-vālaga-】 as in Khot. 【mātṛvālai】, BS 【devapālaka-’】 and ‘*【kāvva-】 from 【kāvya-】 [...]. It is, however, a conjecture to assume that 【kāvya-】 [“poetical composition”] had developed the further special meaning incantation’). Indeed, in view of OKh. 【mātṛ-vālaa-】 ‘priest of the 【mātṛkās’】 and LKh. 【hasta-vālaa-】 ‘elephant-keeper’, it is better to look for the origin of LKh. 【kau-vālaa-】 in an Indian compound with 【°pālaka-】 in conformity with Bailey’s original suggestion. Since LKh. au may correspond not only to OKh. au, but also to 【ā】, 【ū̆】 or 【o】, I have proposed in 【Studia Iranica, Meso- potamica et Anatolica】, 1, 1994, 63-67, to see tentatively in LKh. 【kauvālaa-】 a continuation of an OKh. *【kā-vālaa-】 to be traced back ultimately to Skt. *【kāka-pālaka-】 with 【kāka-】 ‘crow’. With *【kāka-pālaka-】 one can compare Skt. 【kāka-vānī-】 ‘crows* speech’, which occurs in 【Divyāvadāna】 636.28 (ed. Cowell-Neil, Cambridge 1886) in a list of magic arts: 【kākavāṇī ca mantraṃ ca indrajālaṃ ca bhañjanī】)[Emmerick, III, p.42]

Bailey follows Leumann, 【Nordarisch】 113 and E 414 in connecting 【ksīra-】 with Olnd. 【kṣétra-】 ‘field’ and points out that Tumshuqese xšera- prevents connection with Avestan 【xšaθriia-】, an adjective derivative of 【xšaθra-】 ‘realm’. The latter connection was proposed by S. Konow, 【Saka Studies】, Oslo 1932, 153 no doubt on semantic grounds.|||Meantime N. Sims-Williams apud M. Boyce, “Mithra Khšathrapati and his brother Ahura”, 【Bulletin of the Asia Institute】, N.S. 4 (In honor of Richard Nelson Frye: Aspects of Iranian Culture), 1990 [1992], fii. 7 on pp.7-8 has given evidence ‘for the existence of *【χšaiθra-】 as a substandard variant of 【χšaθra-】 “realm” (whether as the result of contamination with *【šaiθra-】 = Avestan 【šōiθra-】 “dwelling-place” or by restoration of the root form 【χšai-】f and points out that *【χšaiθra-】 provides a phonologically unobjectionable etymon for Khotanese 【ksīra-】 and Tumshuqese 【χšera-】 that is semantically more convincing than connection with Avestan 【šōiθra-】 ‘dwelling-place’.

SVK: ‘bell’ (【Dict.】82a): see【ggätāʼka-】‘bell’.|||[III, p.48]

‘bell’(【Dict.】83a)|||Under this heading and elsewhere in【Dict】. Bailey wholly or partially quotes【KV】53.0. The manuscript (Dumaqu 0021 #v4) has: 【kāmä ttätä dasau hāva ce balśa gei’tau’ bañätä】. Bailey offers three partial inter-pretations (and three different readings for 【gei’tau’】):|||1. ‘what are these ten advantages for him who fastens bells on a 【caitya-】shrine (【Dict.】 83 s.v. 【gätā’ka-】； reading 【gä’tau’】as in【KT】5.296); and ‘he [who] fastens bells on the 【caitya-monument】’ (【Dict.】 90 s.v.【 gai’】;reading【gätau’】);|||2. ‘who makes bells ring at the shrine’ (【Dict.】 266 s.v. 【bañätä】with reference to 【ban- 】‘to lament’ [see【Dict.】268 s.v.]; reading【gä’tau’】);|||3. ‘he who makes bells in the shrine (rather ‘makes to sound’)’ (【Dict.】272 s.v.【 balsa-】, reading【gatau’】；for【ban-】 ‘make, cause’ see 【Dict. 】268 s.v.).|||The first of Bailey’s interpretations is correct (cf.【KV】0.52 【dasau hāva ce balśa kṣatru bañätä】‘Ten are the advantages (for him) who fastens an umbrella to a 【stūpa’】). This【bañätä】is thus nothing but the 3 sg. pres. act. of the common verb 【bañ-】 ‘to bind’ (see【Dict.】266 s.v.). The entry 【bañätä】‘makes sound (?)’ can accordingly be deleted from 【Dict】.|||A similar passage (【KV】 0.53) is quoted by Bailey in 【Dict.】 272 s.v. 【balsa-】：【‘kye balśuvo’ bañạ̈tä】 “who in shrines makes (bells (?))”’. In fact, the manuscript clearly has【kye balśa go’ bañätä】 ‘who fastens a bell to a 【stūpa】’. The acc. sg. 【go’ 】is contracted from【 gei’ tau’ 】(< *【gätā’ku; -ei-】 is a variant spelling for 【-ä-】, cf. Z 24《645》【 jsei’ṇu vīrä 】and Z 10《31》【jsäṇu vīri】 ‘in detail’). See also 【KV】pp.93-95.|||[Maggi,III, p.48]

SVK: ‘faeces’|||‘Sid. 10v3【kava hīvī gū】"faeces of fish", BS【śukti-】"mother of pearl", Tib.【ña phyi-saʼ】(Bailey, Dict.). |||Bailey's 【phyi-sa】‘faeces’is a misreading of Tibetan【phyis】. Tibetan【ña-phyis】is the regular rendering of Sanskrit 【śukti】. It is guaranteed by the metre in such places as Vāgbhaṭa, Ah.，【Sū】. 6.53(Peking 29b7) and Rgyud-bźi 2T20《48》.【phyis】 means ‘outside’and refers to the outer part or hard shell. Chos-kyi grags-pa, 【Brda-dag】【miṅ-ćhig】【gsal-ba】, Peking 1957, defines【ña-phyis】accordingly as 【mu-tig-gi】【śun-pa】‘shell of pearl’. In 【An illustrated Tibeto-Mongolian Materia medica of Ayurveda of ʼjam-dpal-rdo­-rje of Mongolia】, ed. Lokesh Chandra, New Delhi 1971, 38《1》 it is written【ña-phyi】and illustrated. The Chinese gloss is石決明(Mathews 5813 + 1697 + 4534) ‘sea-ear Haliotis’, that is, abalone, a species of marine snail. Haliotis is literally‘sea-ear’and describes the appearance of the shell. In Vāgbhaṭa, Ah,【Sū】. 15.43 【śukti】 is glossed【nakha】by Aruṇadatta and Hemādri. This 【nakha】is in turn glossed as【hasti-karṇa】‘elephant ear’ by SoN p. 42 (405). 【nakha】is identified by BhN 236 as the land snail Helix aspera. Hjam-dpal rdo-rje, loc. cit., explains【ña-phyi】as【ña-skyogs】.【skyogs】 is‘to turn’and is used of the same spiral shape. It is found in Tibetan words for the snail: 【skyogs-lto-hbu】 and【 hbu-skyogs】. |||Since in Khotanese【gū】 is well attested as meaning ‘ear’ whereas 【gū】‘faeces’ is not attested, it can be regarded as certain that the Khotanese translator did not, like Bailey, misread 【phyis】as 【phyi-sa】but rendered【ña-phyis】 as ‘ear of fish’. |||It is likely that in Si 2.4 (10v3 【KT】 1.16) a plant was intended since this is a list (Sanskrit 【gaṇa】 or 【varga】) of plants. It could be Euphorbia antiquorum Linn., which is said to have whorled branches and so could have given cause for being named after the spiral or ear-shaped appearan­ce of the snail . |||[Emmerick, I, p.38]

SVK: Bailey posits the stems 【gūha-】and 【gūhaa-】with the meanings ‘harsh, rough or intolerant’ (【Acta Asiatica】, 23, 1972, 66), ‘foot soldier’, ‘brigand’ ‘brigand-like’ (【Dict. 】), ‘rough, ruffian’ (【Culture】 87), ‘savage’ (【KT】 7.79). These meanings require comment.|||The stem【gūha-】, with the meaning ‘foot soldier’ assured by indirect bilingual evidence (【Dict. 】), occurs with certainty only in【Mañj】138 【KBT】 119【beśa aśya hastya gūha rahya tc‹ū›ra-ysanya hīna】 ‘the whole four-fold army (consisting of) cavalry, elephant troops, infantry and charioteers’. On the other hand,【Mañj 】332【KBT】130 has to be read 【ṣā’ mārīña ahna gū habaiśā】 [so Emmerick, not 【gūha baiśa】 as Bailey in 【KBT】and【Dict. 】]【mārā hīna pūrāma】 ‘he has escaped from the noose of Māra, victory over the army of all Māras ...’ with 【gū】 ‹ OKh. *【ggūtä】 3 sg. pf. intr. masc. of 【ggūs-】 ‘to escape, be delivered’ (SGS 31).|||Other occurrences of 【gūha(a)- 】 given in 【Dict.】are ‘III105-6.18-9 [= 【LSt】9c-10a] 【aumācą skarba ttuka ca mara māja kṣīra ttu gūhau grūsīda】 “the harsh minister (BS 【amātya-】), him whom they call here in our country【gūhaa-】 ‘brigand-like””, and 【Rāma】 222【KT】 3.75 【sūpī [[ra]]yāṃ gūhāṃ: kṣīra】, interpreted by Bailey as follows: ‘in the land of the Supīya brigands’ (【Dict. 】)', “‘in the land of the 【Supīya】 ruffians” (【gūhaa-】 “rough”) probably intending bandits’ (【Culture】 87); ‘the land of the savage Sūpīya’ (【KT】 7.79).In other words, Bailey postulates a pejorative meaning ‘brigand’ from ‘foot-soldier’ in 【Dict. 】 89 and, conversely, an improbable semantic development ‘savage, harsh, rough, intolerant’ › ‘ruffian’ › ‘bandit, brigand, brigand-like’ › ‘foot soldier’ in 【Culture】 87 and 【KT】 7.79-80. However, the meanings other than ‘foot soldier’ are conjectured from the context of【LSt】 10a【gūhau】 and of the 【Rāma】 passage, where【sūpī[[ra]]yām gūhām: kṣīra】could merely mean ‘in the land of the Supīya foot soldiers’ or, still better, ‘in the land of the hiding places of the Supīyas’ (from 【gūhā-】, since ‘Buddhist Skt.【guhā】means “hiding place” in general, not just “cave”’, Emmerick,【Studies】 2.37), which is a sufficient characterisation, from the Khotanese viewpoint, for the place where there is an 【āṣeṃjä ... maysairka】 (【Rāma】 222【KT】 3.75), a ‘terrifying pool’ (cf. Z 15《9》【māṃkuya rro īndä heinā khoca u huna ciṃgga supīya kye nä hvatäna-kṣīru bajottāndä】 ‘There are Māṃkuyas, Red Khocas and Hunas, Ciṃggas, Supīyas, who have harmed our Khotanese land’). Accordingly, the only certain meaning of 【gūha(a)- 】 is ‘foot soldier’ (【Mañj】 138【KBT】 119) and the same meaning gives a suitable nickname for the【agrakuleka aląkṣä aumācą】 ‘minister of a prominent family (but) without (noble) qualities’ (【LSt】9c), because, although ‘soldiers on foot, it seems, constituted at all times the bulk of an Indian army, [...] there was little glamour attached to them’ (H. Scharfe, 【The state in Indian tradition】，Leiden 1989, 195).|||[Maggi, III, p.51]
‘faeces (?)’ (Dict. 89b): see 【kharai】.|||[ III, p.51]
‘bell’ (Dict. 90a): see 【ggätā’ka-】 ‘bell’. |||[ III, p.51]

Av. 【xraos-】 ‘schreien’ AIW 533; MPe【 xrwh-】 ‘rufen’ (Verbum, p. 185); Parth. 【xrzvs-, xrzvšt 】‘appeler’ (Ghilain, p. 64) O.Ind. has 【krośati 】‘cries out’.[p.32]

SVK: [not 【graunä-, gronā- 】as Diet. 93]，As suggested by Degener, 【‘Adjektive auf masc. -īnaa- bei einem fem. Bezugswort kommen anscheinend nicht vor.】 AKh 【grauna-】, N-AP【 graune】 ([LKh. P 2957 #78 KBT 35] 【mīrāhīnā graunä “Perlenkränze”】) 【ist wahrscheinlich masc.】’ (Suffice 135 §21.4.7). The word under review is consistently accompanied by masculine adjectives in【 -īnaa-】, not by feminine adjectives in 【-īmgyā】‹ cf. JS 24rl (104) 【vīysfnai graunä 】‘lotus garland’ and LSt 13ab 【spyäkīnai tcesfi grā[[x]]na】. A further indication that 【grauna-】 is masculine is given by the masculine acc. sg. ending of the accompanying adjective tcesfl from 【tcarsua-】 as the LKh. acc. sg. fem.

It is not clear in 【Diet】, what 【grauśe*】 is used to translate. Since in Si 21.34 (133rl 【KT】 1.66)【 ādä】 ‘meal’ corresponds to Sanskrit 【saktubhiḥ】 and Tibetan 【phye】, it will be 【āḍe jsa】 that corresponds to Sanskrit 【saktavaḥ】 in Si 22.12 (134v2 KT 1.70), not 【grauśe】’. Si 22.12 【mau jsa āḍe jsa grauśe’ padīmāñā 】 ‘a paste must be made with liquor (【madyena】) (and) with (barley) meal (【saktavaḥ】. 【grauśe】’ corresponds to Tibetan 【skyo-ma】 ‘pap, paste’. Sanskrit 【saktu】 is rendered by Tibetan 【phye】 ‘flour, meal’ in Si 3.31.8 10.22 21.34 and 25.8. Hence 【hol-kon】, which Bailey could not trace, is likely to be the same as 【hol-skom】, which is explained by Sumatiratna as 【phye-mar】 ‘flour oil’.|||【madyena saktavaḥ】 in Si 22.12 corresponds to 【madyaṃ ... piṣṭakṛtaṃ ... saktubhiḥ】 in Vāgbhaṭa, Ah, Ci.7.12—13, for which the Tibetan has 【phye chaṅ sbyar-ba】 (Peking 159al) ‘flour and liquor mixed’. Caraka, (7i.24.122 has similarly 【saktubhir yuktaṃ ... madyaṃ paiṣṭikamṃ】[Emmerick,I,p.39]

SGS: ‘to cause to digest’ V e tr.|||L.Kh. nom. ag.: 【gvachą̄ñāka】 Si 4V3 【KT】 1. 8 tr. 【hjug-par byed-pa】.|||Et. Caus. ‹ 【gvach-】 q.v.[p.32]

SVK: Si 21.2 (128v3—4 KT 1.60) 【cu be'ti jsa ākṣī'pakä nāma āchai cu yādą aga ne āhrrī idąu gvamą̄nīdeṃ】 is rendered by Bailey ‘what is the wind disease by name 【ākṣepaka-】, (it is his) who is always unable to control his limbs and he is convulsed’.|||Si 21.2 was discussed by me in detail in TPS, 1970 [1971], 115—120. Here in the 【Dict】. s. v. 【gvamānideṃ】 Bailey has clearly accepted my rendering ‘one constantly cannot control the limbs’ (loc. cit. p. 118) whereas in 【Dict】. s. v. 【āhalj-】 he offers the impossible translation ‘the limbs are not stiffened’, giving as the Sanskrit basis ‘BS 【stambha-】" (which is irrelevant here as it belongs to 21.3) instead of 【ākṣepako muhuḥ-kṣepād】.|||【gvamą̄nīdeṃ】 is explained by Bailey as being ‘from 【ava-】 and 【man¬】 in Av. 【vaēmanāt̰】". But which 3 sg. verbal form ends in 【-eṃ】, let alone 【-īdeṃ】' . Bailey makes no suggestion. If however the final anusvāra is regarded as unetymological, like that in the nearby【 īdą 】then 【-idę】 becomes a perfectly normal 3 【plural】 present indicative active ending. Nor is it difficult to locate a plural subject. After the statement that ‘one constantly cannot control the limbs’ the expected consequence is ‘and they (= the limbs) convulse’. That is the rendering offered by me, op.cit. p. 118.|||[Emmerick, I, p40]

(tr.), L.Kh.: 【gvaṣṭai】 JS 35V3 (156) ‘you split’.|||1 sg. pf. intr. m. (intr.), L.Kh.: 【gvaṣṭū】 P 2897. 37 【KT】 2. 116.|||1 pl. pf. intr. m. (intr.), L.Kh. :【gvaṣṭaṃdūṃ】 Or 8212. 162. 59 【KT】 2. 4.|||Et. ‹ *【vi-vaz-】 H. W. B., BSOS, viii. 1, 1935, 123.[p32]

SVK: The evidence for 【gvar-】 ‘distribute’ adduced by Bailey is confined to one passage in Sudh. The line in question is attested in the MSS as follows:|||【baiysūñe dyaume kaiṇa gujsabrrīya】Ch 00266.49 【KBT】 22 ( = C)             【beysūñe dyaume kaiṇą, gvāḍai】 P 2025.88 【KBT】 14 ( = P)|||【biysūñi dyāme kaṇa gvāḍe】. P 2896.6 【KBT】 12 ( = D)|||According to Bailey the meaning of 【gvāḍai】 in P (=【 gvāḍe】 in D) is guaranteed by its correspondence with 【gujsabrrīya】 in C. He renders C by ‘for the bodhi-vision he strewed’ and P by ‘for the bodhi-vision he distributed’. By themselves these renderings do not make much sense. In his translation of Sudh in BSOAS, XXIX.3, 1966, 506 Bailey assigns the words 【beśa tta dāvīnā rana】 as object to 【gujsabrrīya】 and renders: ‘For the sake of bodhi-vision he scattered all these 【dharma-ratna】.However, he does not explain what that could mean. His commentary on p. 515 is devoted entirely to the etymology of 【gvāḍai】.|||[Emmerick,II,p37]
see gūha.[Emmerick,II,p39]

Earlier Bailey regarded 【gvahan-】 as meaning to ‘mount up’ as ‘opposed to 【vahaṃda】 “descended”’ [BSOAS, X. 3, 1940, 570, 593). Now he apparently regards 【gvahan-】 and 【vahan-】 as basically the same in meaning and also in etymology. In the case of 【gvahan-】 he gives the same explanation of【 °han- 】as found s. v. 【vahan-】 but he makes no comment on 【gva-】. However, the three items immediately following 【gvahan-】 in the Diet, (【gvahai‘ñä, gvahaiya, gvahaiśkye】) are all assigned to *【ava-xad-】, which shows that Bailey regards 【gva-】 as a variant of 【va-】 from *【ava-】. At least that is what he seems to have decided by the time he reached p. 95. Earlier in the 【Dict】., p. 90 s. v. 【guhei】, two of the above words, namely, 【gvahai‘ñä】 and 【gvahaiya】, are correctly derived from *【vi-xad-】 . In the case of 【gvahai’ñä】 the derivation from an older 【gūhaiñä】 is made likely by the attestation of 【gūhaiñä】 in JS 13v2 (55). All the words mentioned so far beginning with 【gva-】 are Late Khotanese.【 gva-】 is merely a Late Khotanese development from 【gu-】.|||Thus, 【gvahan- 】is likely also to be Late Khotanese for *【guhan-】. Neither ‘mount up’ nor ‘descend’ is very plausible for a verb of motion with the preverb *【vi-】.|||[Emmerick,I,p41]

gvā- 【'yellow, green, as first component (Dict.)】|||【gvā- 】is not ‘yellow, green’ from a base 【gau-】 but a Late Khotanese spelling of Old Khotanese 【ggūna-】 ‘colour’.|||【gvā-ysirūṃ āchai 】in Si 14.21 (107vl KT 1.46) corresponds to Tibetan 【nad Ijaṅ-gu kha】 ‘green-coloured disease’ and Sanskrit 【halīmaka】, a disease associated with jaundice. On 【halīmaka】 see Meulenbeld pp. 312—313 and 627. Also in Si 14.21 we have 【aṃgāṃ hīya vī cha gvā-ysirų̄na hame】 ‘the complexion of the limbs becomes 【gvā-ysirų̄na】' corresponding to Tibetan 【lus-kyi mdog Ijaṅ-gu khar hdug-pa】 ‘the colour of the body is green¬coloured’ and to Sanskrit harita-. The disease is called【 gvāṃ-ysirūṃ āchai halīmakä】 in Si 14.22 (107v4 KT 1.46), where the Tibetan has 【nad Ijaṅ-gu kha】 ‘green-coloured disease’.|||Tibetan Ijaṅ-gu ‘green’ is used by itself to render Sanskrit 【harita-】 in Si 6.4, 8.5, and 17.3 and Khotanese 【ysarū】 is used by itself to render Skt. 【harita】 in the Sanskrit-Khotanese bilingual P5538b77 【KT】 3.124.|||Since gvā(ṃ) is apparently superfluous Bailey has suggested that itmeans the same as 【ysirūṃ】 and explains it as belonging ‘to base 【gau-: gu-】 “yellow, green” ’. However, there is no other evidence that gvā(ṃ) means ‘yellow, green’.|||[Emmerick,II,p38]

SGS: meaning uncertain, mid. A/B|||3 pl. pres, mid., L.Kh.: 【gvīthāre】 Ch 00266. 9 【KT】 3. 34 = 【gvīthārä】 P 2025. 17 【KT】 3. 46; 【gvīthą̄rä】 P 2025. 65 KT 3. 47 = 【gvīthāva】 P 2956. 44 KT 3. 38.|||Et. ?[p.32]

‘to talk’ V b intr. ppp. 【gvīḍa-】;【 guḍa-】|||O.Kh. pres. pt.: 【gvīranda】 Z 23. 141.|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【gūḍe】 P 2957. 88 【KBT】 35 = 【guḍe】 P 2025. 218 【KBT】 18 =【 gvīḍa】 Ch 00266. 143 【KBT】 26.|||3 sg. pf. tr. f., L.Kh.: 【gvīḍā】 P 2025. 242 【KBT】 19 = id. P 2957. 105 【KBT】 36 =【 gvīḍa 】Ch 00266. 160【 KBT】 27.|||3 pl. pf. tr. (f.), L.Kh.: 【guḍāda】 Ch 00266. 214 【KBT】 30. 【gvīḍa-】 secondary ‹ 【gvīr-】; [gūḍa- ]‹ *【vi-vṛta-】, cf. 【hauḍa- 】/ 【hūḍa- 】‹ 【haur-】,|||Et. ‹ *【vi-var-ya-】, cf. IE 6. *【u̯er- 】‘feierlich sagen’ (Pok. 1162-3), Av. 【varah-】 ‘ordeal’ etc., H. W. B. against TPS, 1945, 21 (cf. Oss. D. iüarun ‘to divide, share’). Cf.【 śver-】 p. 126.[p.33]

‘to reveal; explain’ V e act. tr. A/B|||3 pl. pres, act.: O.Kh.,【 gverīndi 】Z 22. 330; L.Kh., 【gverīdä】 P 5538a33 【KT】 2. 127; 【gvairrīda】 P 5538b 71 【KT】 3. 123 tr. 【kathaiyattī】.|||Et. Caus. ‹ *【vi-var- 】S. Konow, NTS, xi, 1939, 49. See 1. 【gvīr-】,[p.33]

SVK: ‘from 【 caṃ, canda-】, Sid. 124v3 【caṃ tcerai’ (Diet.)】|||caṃ tcerai in Si 19.27 (124v3 KT 1.54) is merely a mistake for *vricam tcerai ‘a cathartic (【virecanam】) must be administered’. The corresponding Tibetan has 【bkru-sman btaṅ-ṅo】 ‘a cathartic must be administered’. For Si 19.27 see s. v. 【pvāñā】 ‘to be smeared upon’.

【cakurikā-】 is attested several times in Khotanese texts as the rendering of the Sanskrit plant name 【cāṅgerī】, which has generally been identified as the wood sorrel Oxalis corniculata Linn. In Si 3.21.3 (17v3 【KT】 1.28) the derivative adjective 【cukurīkīji】 is found.|||Among the synonyms of Sanskrit 【cāṅgerī】 is 【cukrikā】 (RājN 175 and 439 (41)). 【cukrikā】 is evidently a derivative of the *【cukrá- ‘sour】* implied, by Sanskrit 【cukra-】 ‘a sour juice’ and later Indian forms (see Mayrhofer s. v. 【cukráḥ】; Turner, CDIAL 4850).【 cukrikā】 is listed in Vāgbhaṭa, Ah., Ci.7.31 as one of the five sour juices (【pañcāmlako】).|||It is accordingly clear that 【cakurīkā- 】(adjective 【cukurīkīji】) is a loanword from Sanskrit 【cukrikā】 and not, as Bailey tries to prove, a word of Iranian origin ‘from base 【čak-】 “be pointed, horned”, with suffixes 【čaku-】 with 【-ra-】’. In a word of Iranian origin the regular development of Old Iranian *【č-】 would be to 【tc-】 as in 【tcei’man-】 ‘eye’ from *【čašman- 】(Avestan čašman-).|||See Die Sprache, 29, 1983.[Emmerick,I,p43]

The word 【caksa】 has been noticed so far only in MT a.i.0044b3 KI 5.386: 【khvau tcimñāsta caksa parīhauda】, which Bailey here renders ‘if he deigns to give 【caksa】 for our eyes’. In 【Saka documents text volume】, London 1968, 78 Bailey commented that ‘The 【caksa】 are unknown, hardly from BS 【caksus-】 eye’, but in the Diet, he suggests that 【caksa】 is ‘possibly from BS 【caksus-】 as “eye-medicament”’.|||It is clear from the context that 【caksa】 is a medicament that is inserted into the eye to effect a cure. Such a medicament is known from Si 26.22, where a prescription is given based on the powder from what is called in the Khotanese version (147v4 KT 1.92) cahä:sa. Khotanese 【cahä:sa】 renders Tibetan 【mig-sman caksu】 ‘the eye medicine 【caksu】’. The Sanskrit original has 【äranya-kulattha】 ‘wild horse gram’. It is accordingly clear that 【caksu】 represents Sanskrit 【caksusyā】 (lit. ‘beneficial to the eye’), which is given in RājN 341 as a synonym of āranya-kulatthikā[Emmerick,II,p40]

BHS 【carati】 ‘practises’.[p.33]

SVK: No evidence is given for the assumption that 【cāmnä】 in Si 2.20 (13r2 【KT】 1.20) 【only】 is a plant name and not 【cq›nä】 ‘powder’, that is Sanskrit|||【cūrna】, which occurs commonly in JP. In fact the context of Si 2.20 actually excludes the possibility that it could be a plant name, 【mauskakä bahyä si’ cu cqnä】 means ‘the muṣkaka tree, that (is its) powder’ and corresponds to 【muskaka-】 alone in the Sanskrit text. The construction is as in Si 2.15 (12r4【 KT】 1.18): 【sumana-sāriva si’cu symam hīya bāva】 ‘white Indian sarsaparilla, that (is), the root of the white (kind)’, which corresponds to 【śārivā】 alone in the Sanskrit original.|||Note 【cqna'm】 JP [90] 115v2【 KT】 1.193 rendering Sanskrit cūrnam in Si 8.12. [e]Emmerick,I,p43]'beeswax'[not 'plant name'][Emmerick,III,p52]

No evidence is given for the assumption that 【cāṃṇä】 in Si 2.20 (13r2 【KT】 1.20) only is a plant name and not 【cą̄ṇä】 ‘powder’, that is Sanskrit 【cūrṇa】, which occurs commonly in JP. In fact the context of Si 2.20 actually excludes the possibility that it could be a plant name, 【mauṣkakä bahyä ṣi’ cu cą̄ṇä】 means ‘the muṣkaka tree, that (is its) powder’ and corresponds to 【muṣkaka-】 alone in the Sanskrit text. The construction is as in Si 2.15 (12r4 KT 1.18):【 sumana-śāriva ṣi’cu sųmaṃ hīya bāva】 ‘white Indian sarsaparilla, that (is), the root of the white (kind)’, which corresponds to【śārivā】 alone in the Sanskrit original.Note 【cą̄ṇä】 in JP [90] 115v2 KT 1.193 rendering Sanskrit 【cūrṇaṃ】 in Si 8.12. [Emmerick,II,p40]

【cāyūm】 is assumed by Bailey to mean ‘I consume’ and to be required in one passage only: JP [61] 99v2—3 【KT】 1.181. His reading and interpretation are as follows:【 ‘khvim (-im = -ai) ksamīsa khu vrrī cāyūm svīdanim (-im = -ai) gūlya khāśā’ña, ttūmgara】 “when it pleases him, to think 【(sa)】, How shall I consume a vire&a-purgative, ginger must be drunk by him with milk, with molasses”, BS 【ksīrānvita(m) viriktaś ca khāde(d) viśva-gudānvita(m)】 “and let him consume with milk, ginger with molasses”.’|||[Emmerick,II,p41]

DKS: ‘to save’, contamination of 【trāy-】 and 【ttuvāy-】.See also 【trāy-】 and 【ttuvāy-】.
Here 【-au】 may be pronoun, either 【-āṃ】 ‘of us’ or 【-ū】 ‘of you’.

SGS: 【tvaśd-】 ‘to transfer’ VI b act. tr. A/B；3 pl. pres, act., L.Kh.: 【tvaśdīm‹dä›】；2 pl. imper., L.Kh.: 【tva‹śdya›】；【tvaśdyarä】；【ttvaśdyari】[p.41]
【tvāñ-】‘to strengthen’ V e mid. tr. A；3 sg. pres., L.Kh.: 【tvą̄ñä】；3 pl. pres, mid., L.Kh.: 【tvāñāre】；L.Kh. nom. ag.: 【tvą̄ñāka】[p.41]

SVK: 【tvyā】is not ‘of them’ but locative plural feminine of the demonstra¬tive pronoun.‘among these’.[Emmerick,Ⅰ,p.53]
[Maggi,Ⅲ,75]

SGS: 【tsām-】‘to swallow’ tr. ppp. 【*tsaunda-】；L.Kh. pt. nec.: 【tsą̄mą̄ña】 JP 84V5 KT 1. 169; 【tsāmāña】；3 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【tsodi】.[p.41]

【tsu-】 ‘to go’ I b act. intr. B ppp. 【tsuta-】；1 sg. pres, act., O.Kh.: 【tsīmä】；2 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【tsai】；3 sg. pres, or opt., O.Kh.: 【tsīyä】；3 pl. pres, act.: O.Kh., 【tsīndi】 Z 2. 135++; L.Kh., 【tsīda】； 1 sg. subj., O.Kh.: 【tsīñi】 ；2 sg. imper., O.Kh.:【 tso 】； 3 sg. inj., O.Kh.: 【tsūta】；O.Kh. pt. nec.: 【tsuñaa-】；O.Kh. ppp. 【tsuta-】, once 【tsva-】; L.Kh. 【tsva-】, 【tsa-】；2 sg. pf. tr. m. (intr.): O.Kh., 【tsutai】；3 sg. pf. tr. m. (intr.), O.Kh.: 【tsute】；3 pl. pf. tr. (intr.): O.Kh., 【tsutāndi】Z 2. 24+; 【tsvāndi】 Z 24. 514; L.Kh., 【tsvāṃdä】；L.Kh. inf.: 【tsai】  ；[p.42]

SVK: [Emmerick,Ⅱ,p.51]
【thā】 is not a unique verb form but a regular LKh. spelling of the 2 sg. pers. pronoun ‘you’ (= OKh. 【thu】).[Emmerick,Ⅱ,p.51]
【thāna-】 ‘place’ is well known in Khotanese. It is a hybrid based on Prakrit 【thana】 and Sanskrit 【sthāna】.[Emmerick,Ⅰ,p.51]

DKS: Ⅲ 41.39, read 【brrī】 with incomplete 【b-】, as in Ⅲ 48.71 【brrī】.

SVK: [Emmerick,Ⅱ,p.51]
【thurs-】is ‘to be harmed’ not ‘to harm’.[Emmerick,Ⅱ,p.51]

SGS: ‘to burn’ I b act. tr. (?); mid. intr. B|||3 pl. pres, act., O.Kh.: 【dajsīndä】 Kha 001306. a3 【KT】 5. 125.|||3 sg. pres. mid. intr., L.Kh.: 【daysdi】 Hed. 17. 3, 5, 13, 15, 17 【KT】 4- 3i-|||Et. Av. 【dag-】 ‘urere’, pres. 2 daz̆a- (【AIW】 675); O.Ind. 【dáhati】. Parth. '【wdj- ‹ *ava-dag-】 (Ghilain, p. 51).[p.43]

DKS: ‘to tame’，present 【dīm-】, participle 【danda-】, K 9, 43v4 【aysm‹u›ī dīmāmata】 ‘control of mind’, parallel BS 【cittasya damanam-】
‘to blow,breathe’, participle 【daunda-】, Z 23.160 【śśaṅga damīndä】 ‘they blow the conchs’; Z 19.88 【damäte】 ‘it is blown’;
SGS: ‘to blow’ V a act. tr. A|||3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【damäte】 Z 19. 88.|||3 pl. pres. act.: O.Kh., 【damīndä】 Z 23. 160; L.Kh., 【damīda】 P 2928. 33 【KT】 3. 106.|||Et. O.Ir. *【dam-】 ‘blow’ in Av. only in 【dāδmainya-】 ‘sich aufblasend’ (【AIW】 731-2) and 【duz̆dąfǝδrō】 V. 19. 43 ‘qui respire difficilement’ (Benv., 【MO】, xxvi-xxvii, 1932-3, 179-80). O.Ind. 【dhámati】 ‘blows’. Parth. 【dm-】 ‘souffler’ (Ghilain, p. 56); MPe 【dm-】 ‘atmen’ (【Verbum】, p. 173); NP 【damīdan】 ‘to blow’. B. Sogd. has extended *【dmā-】 in δm’s’t ‘swollen’ P 7. 61 (I. G., 【GMS】, § 318, p. 49).[p.43]

DKS: ‘to make’, JS 25v4 【thaṃ vaska dātīnai cirau didai】 ‘you for them made the lamp of the 【dharma-】doctrine’; dedū ‘we made’, Ⅱ 77.17-8 【pvaica masai dedū hūḍai】 ‘we made only a covering to give’ (beside 17 【hūḍāmdū】 ‘we gave’); from participle 【danda-】 to base 【dam-】, see【 padīm-, padanda-】.
‘hold’see 【darra-, dār-, -dāraa-, der-, pader-, haṃdār-】, replaced by 【dṛjs-】.

SVK: ‘thick’|||Bailey’s dara- ‘thick’ does not exist. It is based on a misinterpreta¬tion of two passages from the Si.|||Si 26.55 (151v5—152r3 KT 1.98) describes a remedy for timira (an eye disease), which involves among other things slitting open a chebulic myrobalan (Sanskrit abhayā) to extract the stone and putting in its place a particular preparation. The slit or split made in the myroba¬lan must be covered over with dough before the myrobalan is put in a fire. This process is described in the Khotanese thus: darq hāmai jsa esalyāñä ‘the split must be smeared (digdha-) with dough’. That darq hāmai does not mean ‘thick pap, dough’ is confirmed by Si 26.57 (152r5 KT 1.98), where we find grihqjsa ttū kamalq darq, esalyāñä ‘the severed head (of the snake) must be smeared with clay’.|||The second passage (Si 26.82 = 155v2—3 KT 1.102) is more difficult. Bailey renders darq ysirrā as ‘thick rough’ {Diet. s. v. dara-}, ‘thick, rough’ {Diet. s. v. banaji}, and ‘scraped rough’ {Diet. s. v. ysira-}. However, ‘thick’ and ‘scraped’ are quite different. The latter can be justified by reference to the verb dar- ‘to scrape’ and is in accord with dara- ‘split, severed’ in the passages discussed above. But the meaning ‘thick’ is based on this passage alone. Since the Tibetan version has here ril-gyis stug-po ‘wholly thick’ and not ‘rough’ whereas the Khotanese has ysirrä ‘rough’ it is unsafe to deduce that darq must mean ‘thick’ here only, darq ysirrä may just as well mean ‘cracked (and) rough’, cf. Sanskrit sphutitā used of the tongue disease due to wind in 26.80.|||This dara- ‘split, severed’ is a Late Khotanese spelling of darra- ‘broken’: see below s, v. darra- ‘unbroken’! [Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.54]

‘unbroken’|||Bailey claims that in 【Śgs】 3.14r2 【vysnora kye hamo darrä】 means ‘beings whose bowl is unbroken’ and not as in my edition (p. 47) ‘beings who have a broken vessel’. It is difficult, however, to see how 【darrahamau】 in 【Śgs】 3.14vl could be construed so as to agree with 【balysūñavūysā hvañāre】 ‘they are called Bodhisattvas’. Moreover, since Late Khotanese has 【dara-】 in the sense of ‘split, severed’ (see s. v. 【dara-】 ‘thick’ ！), it is improbable that it should also have 【darra-】 ‘unbroken’.|||It is dangerous to assume that 【darre】 in Z 20.43 should mean ‘held together’ (which Bailey appears to consider synonymous with ‘unbroken’) since more or less everything in these cemetery scenes is broken, torn, split, etc. What about nearby 【darra】 in Z 20.38, 39? In Z 20.39 【darra】 is used of a thread that has been struck. Bailey renders this 【darra】 as ‘torn up’ (【Dict.】 s. w. 【anāskotta, ṣṣonda】), which is similar to my rendering ‘split asunder’. Indeed, wherever there is clear evidence it points to the meaning ‘broken’ rather than ‘unbroken’.|||【darra-】 ‘broken’ can be etymologised easily. It is from *【dṛna-】 and can be compared with Old Indian 【dīrṇa-《1》】 . Bailey’s 【darra-】 ‘unbroken’ on the other hand implies a participle *dṛna- that goes against both Avestan ddrdta- and Old Indian 【dhṛtá-】.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]

DKS: adjective to a place-name *【darauysa-】, v 209, ooIaI 【darauysāṃ ṣau khrrī dārrjai】 ‘the 【ṣau-】official Khri dorjeof Darauysa’, to Tib.【khri】‘seat’, 【rdo-rj̆e】 ‘BS 【vajra-】', hence for 【vajrāsana-】.
‘ten’, K 43.Ⅰ36 【daśā māśt(a) parsāme jsa】 ‘with the passing of ten months’, =K 40.18 【daśau māśtāṃ jsa.】 See 【dasau】 ‘ten’.
gen. plur. ‘ten’, 11 105*107 【daśaina hāvām】 ‘of ten benefits’ = ibid. 111-2. See 【dasau】 ‘ten’.

SVK: ‘section’ or ‘arrangement’ (Dict.)|||In addition to 【dasa】 ‘thread’, Old Ind. 【daśā-】, Bailey has the entry 【dasa】 ‘section’ or ‘arrangement’. This 【dasa】 is according to him found in two places, once in ApS and once in MPPS (the commentary on the Hṛdayasūtra).[Skjærvø, Ⅱ,p.57]

‘loc. plur. ‘group’|||dastakvā ‘group’ is based on an arbitrary interpretation of P 3510.3.1 [11] 【KBT】 48. There 【ayīṣṭe dastakvā】 ‘I bless with (my) hands’ is closely parallel with 【dastakvā haudvyā ... ayaiṭha】 T bless with both hands’ in 【Deśanā】 78r3 【KBT】 63. In both contexts the expression precedes the 【pūjā-karma】 (act of reverence) and in both contexts the object of the blessing is the Buddhas in the hair-pores.|||【dastaka】 in Z is confined to the hands in the añjali position (2.63 22.188).|||See Stwlia iranica, 9.2, 1980, 189.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]

DKS: first component, 【dā-gūna-】 ‘fire-coloured’, K 18.193-4 【saramadā-gūna karavīnā bveya harrida】 ‘red, around, rays shine’
see daurmīnai, from *【durma-】, Ⅱ60.17 【dāṃrmīnai ṣkāma dale śau】; Ⅱ77.23 【daurmīnai bagala.】

SGS: ‘to complete, finish’ ? V e act. tr. A ppp. 【*dāśśäta-】|||3 sg. pres., O.Kh.: 【dāśśäte】 Z 10. 26; 【dāśätä】 N 50. 37.|||3 pl. pres, act., L.Kh. 【dāśīde】 Or 11344. 3b4 【KT】 2. 33.|||+ inf.: 【padīde】 Z 23.36; 【naskośä】 N 50.37.|||+pres. pt. (?): 【dāśādūṃ paphūjā】 Hed. 3v6 【KT】 4.23 ‘we have completed collecting’. Cf. 【ākṣuv-】 p.7.|||L.Kh. ppp.【dāśya-, dāśa- ‹ *dāśśäta-\ dāśyā JP】 47v3 【KT】 1. 139 tr. 【samāptta】; 3 sg. pf. tr. m.: 【dāśe】 【JS】 13v1 (55) +inf. 【tsai】; 3 sg. pf. tr. f.: 【dāśā JS】 8r4 (31) +inf. 【hīsä】; 3 pl. pf. tr.: 【dāśāṃdä】 P 3513. 46r1 (Asm. 13).|||Et. H. W. B. cf. Oss. D. 【dāsun, dāst】 ‘heap up; cut’.[p.45]

DKS: ‘may I see’, to base 【dai-】 ‘to see’, Z 2.100 【ma ne dīñi】 ‘may I not see’.
‘seen’ and ‘appearance’, for verbal forms see 【dai-】 ‘to see’;
SVK: ‘seen’ and ‘appearance’ (【Dict.】 158b)|||Bailey reads P 2928 #10 (【LSt】 4c) 【dya vī】 in 【KT】 3.105 and quotes 【dya vī śairka】 in 【Dict.】 150 s.v. da together with Ch 1.002la,a #33 【KT】 2.55 【da śerka】 ‘fine in appearance’, 【JS】 5r3 (16) 【di śirka】, thus giving the impression of understanding 【dya vī】 as containing the postposition 【vī】 ‘in, at, on’ and meaning ‘in appearance’. The impression is confirmed by the fact that he again quotes 【dya vī śairka】 ‘good to look at’ in 【Dict.】 165 s.v. 【dya】 beside 【Mañj】 206 【KBT】 123 【khu tterthyā dya vī】 ‘as in sight of the sectaries’, which is better translated ‘as in the (false) view of the heretics’. However, ‘in the (false) view’ is not the same as ‘in appearance’. A different interpretation is apparently hinted at in 【Dict.】 158 s.v. 【däta-】, where Bailey, after quoting P 3513 #72rl 【KT】 1.248 (【Suv】 [3.83]) '【dya-vīya】 “having a good appearance”, BS 【abhirūpa-】' adds: ‘Also Ⅲ 105.10 【dya-vī śairka】'. Although Degener, 【Suffixe】 309, correctly points out that most instances of LKh. 【-vī】 are not likely to be spellings of the OKh. suffix 【-vīya-】 and that 【dya-v-ī śairka】 in the passage under consideration could be translated ‘sein Aussehen war schön’, I prefer to follow Bailey’s hint and translate 【LSt】 4cd daha' 【pūra dvyavī śairka | uspūryau aidrrā jsa khū *śakax《1》】 as ‘a male child, good-looking, beautiful, with complete senses as Sakra’. In fact, an adjective 【dyavī】 ‘good-looking’ (from 【dya-vīya-】 ‹ OKh. *【däta-vīya-】) is more appropriate in the present context: it is the boy who is endowed 【uspūryau aidrrājsa】 ‘with complete senses’, not its appearance. Degener’s interpretation has possibly been influenced by Bailey’s provisional metrical arrangement that separates daha ’ 【pūra】 and 【dyavī śairka】 in two 【pādas】.|||《1》 For MS ścāka see below s.v.|||[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.75]

‘so much’ (Dict. 158b)|||Under this heading Bailey lists also ‘V 301, 27r2 【dädä ku】', without translation, from 【KV】 15.3 【dädä ku yä】 [ro 【aysmūjna yąnde】 ‘The third (act by which a man obtains birth in hell) is when one [also] performs (it = a great evil deed) with the mind’, Skt. 【tīvrampradusta-cittasya ... -mano- duścaritam】. In fact, OKh. 【dädä】 can only mean ‘third’ (see 【Dict.】 169 s.v. 【drai】). [Maggi，Ⅲ，p.76]

‘stone’ (Diet. 158-159)|||Under this heading Bailey has, among other instances of the word, ‘possibly II 41.10 dädä “stone for mounting (?)’”. The same interpretation is found in 【SDTV】 1.115 and 117 (【'dädä from *dädyä from dädäya-'】). The sentence containing this dädä is Ch 0048 #10 【KT】2.41 【padauysä aśä parauvā va pathāñä dädä spāśāña khu parauva-bara bvä'ttä】 ‘The first horse must be harnessed for the orders there (and) watched until the dispatch-rider mounts’. LKh. 【dädä khu】 means ‘so much that, until’ and 【dädä】 is just a variant spelling of LKh. 【daṃda-】 ‘so much’ (see 【Dict.】 151 s.v. 【daṃda-】 and 158 s.v. 【dida-】).|||Cf. above s.v. 【dida-】[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.76]

SGS: ‘to tame’ V e tr. ppp. danda-|||O.Kh. 【-āmatā】 abstract: 【dīmāmatā-】 Kha 1. 309a1. 43v4 【KBT】 9.|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., O.Kh.: 【dąnde】 Z 24. 273.|||ppp., O.Kh.: 【danda-】 Zb. 20; L.Kh., 【daṃda-】 【JS】17r4 (73).|||Et. ‹ *【damaya-】, cf. O.Ind. 【damáyati】 ‘overpowers’. Cf. H. W. B., 【KT】 4. 163. *【dam-】 is attested in Kh. in the 【-gyā】 abstract: 【daṃgyo Suv】. K. 67r5 【KT】 5. 118 tr. 【damanaṃ】; 【dagye】 ibid. 66r5 【KT】 5. 117 tr.【damana-】(v. H. W. B., 【JRAS】, 1961, 55). O.Ir. *【dam-】, cf. Oss. D. 【domun】 ‘dompter’ (Benv., 【Oss.】, p. 90); Chor.【 δms-】 ‘be tamed’ (W. B. Henning, 【Togan】 Vol., p. 434)[p.45]

SVK: ‘bad’ (【Dict】. 159a)|||Bailey devotes the following entry to this ghostword:|||‘V 301, 27r2 【därä bäśāna yande】 “he acts with evil tongue”; ibid. 27r2-3 【dä‹rä aysmū›na】 “with evil mind”; ibid. 27v3 ‘【dasamä sä kyera dära u‹ysāne jsa?>】 “this is tenth, as much as with evil self’. Possibly 【dire】 in III, 9-10 【dire vā anāspeti paśāñä yem】 “I have sent the bad, the refugeless ones”. See 【dara-】 “bad”. Possibly from 【adara-】 “inferior”’.|||The first three examples are from 【KV】 15.2, 15.3 and 15.10 respectively. The correct readings are: 【KV】 15.2-3 【u śätä ṣä ku yä ro bäśāna yande . dädä ku yä [ro aysmū]na yąnde】 ‘And the second is also when one performs (it, i.e. a great evil deed) with the tongue. The third is [also] when one performs (it) with the mind’, Skt. 【tīvram praduṣṭa-cittasya ...-vāṅ- mano-duścaritam】 (Lévi, 【KV】 44.10); 【KV】 15.10 u 【dasamä ṣä kye atärañ[ī näjsasde]】, Skt 【akr̥tajñatā】 (Lévi, 【KV】 44.11). The fourth example (Balawaste 0154 #9 【KT】 3.131) is a Late Khotanese spelling for 【dīra-】 ‘weak’ (see Emmerick, 【Studies】 1.55-56). See 【KV】 pp.108-109 and 110-111.[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.77]

The meaning ‘bad’ is secondary, the primary meaning being ‘weak’. dīra- ‘weak’ is opposed to 【pata'jsa】 ‘powerful’ in Z 10.2, and it is used dyadically with 【duspäta】 ‘powerless’ in Z 24.270. Hence the derivation of 【dīra- ‹ *dirga ‹ *drigu-】 cf. Avestan 【drigu-】 ‘arm, bedürftig, schwach’, proposed by Henning in 【JRAS】, 1944, 141 n. 7, should not be silently discarded. Moreover, 【dīramggāra-】 ‘evil-doing’ is a rare type of compound with inflection of the first member, which is matched exactly by Buddhist Sogdian 【SryiFnk'r'k】. See on 【śśära-】 ‘good’ below.|||See already 【JRAS】, 1969, 65.[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.55]|||‘bad’ (【Dict.】 159)|||The phrase 【dīrä (dīra) yan- act】. ‘to cause to be ill’ (not recorded in 【Dict.】) occurs three times in Ch. 00217a-c 【KT】 3.135 (under the signature Stein 117.1-3).《1》 Its meaning is assured by both the context and the corresponding, though not parallel, Chinese text (‘this spirit is the cause of the trouble’, translation by A. Waley, 【A catalogue of paintings recovered from Tun-huang by Sir Aurel Stein】, London 1931, pp. 171 -172) and lends support to the meaning ‘weak’ for 【dīra-】 and to its derivation from OIr. *【drigu-】, cf. Avestan 【drigu-】 ‘arm, bedürftig, schwach’ (see Emmerick, Studies 1.55-56).|||Judging by OKh. 【śśäru yan- act】. ‘to do good’ (【Z】 2《7》+), LKh. 【-ä/-a】 in 【dīrä (dīra) yan-】 is from OKh. 【-u 】‹ OIr. *【-am】. This is confirmed by the fact that the phrases 【dīrä (dīra) yan-】 and 【śśäru yan-】 correspond to the compounds 【Z】 2《69》 【dīram-ggāra-】 ‘evil-doer’ and, respectively, 【Śgs】2.4v2 【śäram-gāra-】 ‘well-doer, friend’ with inflection of the first member (cf. Emmerick, Studies 1.55-56 and 1.117-118).|||Note that a difference is made between 【dīrä (dīra) yan-】 with active verb and the frequent 【dīra kädagāne yan-】 ‘to do evil acts’ with middle verb (cf. Canevascini, ‘Medio-reflexive verbs in Khotanese’, in 【Mac¬Kenzie Fs.】 23-26).|||Cf. 【Studia Iraniea Mesopotamica et Anatolica】, 1, 1994, 67-68. See also s.v. *【dära-】 ‘bad’.|||《1》 The phrase seems to occur also in the unclear sentence 【JP】 47v2 【KT】 1.139 【haṣṭav-ī dīra na īdä】, on which see Emmerick, 【JEĀS】, 2, 1992, 80.[Maggi，Ⅲ，p.77]

【haṃdarai dīśīra】 in Rāma 208 (47) 【KT】 3.74 is rendered by Bailey ‘some were throwing it out’. A more plausible rendering is ‘some were making it burn’: see above s. v. 【gvahan-】.|||【dīś-】 is derived by Bailey from ‘base 【dag-】, with 【dag-ś-y-】 to 【diś-】’ Bailey’s etymology was reported by me in 【SGS】 46. Meantime E. Tichy has shown that 【dīś-】 derives from *【daisaya-】 from IE *【deik̑-】 ‘to throw’ attested also in Greek διϰεϊν ‘to throw’ (【MSS】, 38, 1979, 171—228).[Emmerick,Ⅰ, p.56]
SGS: dīśś-  ‘to throw’ H. W. B., 【BSOS】, viii. 121, 1935. V e tr. ppp. 【dīsta-】|||L.Kh. pt. nec.: 【dīśąñą,, dīśą̄ñä】 Si 153v2 【KT】 1. 100 tr. 【bor】.|||2 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【dīṣṭai】【JS】 6v2 (23); 9v1(36).|||3 sg. pf. tr. m., L.Kh.: 【dīṣṭe】 Ch 00266. 203 【KBT】 29 = 【nīśāve】 P 2957-138【KBT】38. ’ .|||Et. H. W. B., cf. 【daxs̆-】 ‘throw’ in Av. 【fradaxs̆anā】- ‘sling’, 【dīśś-】 is then caus. ‹ inch, of *【dag-】 ‘throw’, and Av. has an 【s-】extension (cf. Av. 【bag-】, 【baxs̆-】, etc.). I. G. draws my attention to B. Sogd. 【’nδyščy】 ‘Verwerfen’, d.i. 【pratikṣepa】 ST, ii. 575 s.v. From a base *dai- (with s-extension in Sogd.), the inch, should be *【dĭs-】. However, all presents of class V e in 【-śś】 have a long vowel in the root syllable.[p.46]

SVK: ‘is put in" (【Dict.】)|||‘Sid. 15r3 【jsä’ñāñä daṃda khu si’ *kaṣā】’ (MS 【cuṣā】’) 【dīṣḍa】 “to be boiled; so much this kaṣaya- decoction is to be poured in” ’ (【Dict.】).|||Bailey proposes to see in 【dīṣḍa】 the 3 sg. pres. mid. form of an unattested present stem *【dīṣṣ-】 ‘from 【dagš-】’. He deduces the meaning from the Tibetan, of which he writes: ‘Tib. 【sman-gyi khu-ba du-nas (hdu】 “combine”; 1. 3 【du-bar byaho = niśāña-】)’. It is not clear, however, why Bailey translates 【dīṣḍa】 as ‘is to be poured in’ in his rendering of the passage quoted, as if 【dīṣḍa】 were a participle of necessity. The rendering given is misleading for a second reason also, 【jṣą̄ñāñä daṃdä khu】 is a common phrase in medical texts and means ‘it is to be boiled until’ or ‘it is to be boiled so much that’. Bailey’s rendering disregards 【khu】 and the general usage of the phrase.[emmerick, Ⅱ , p.59]

Bailey interprets 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 23.17 (137r5 KT 1.74) as ‘it must be besmeared’. He wishes to separate 【dva-】 ‘smear’ from 【dvya-】 ‘to beat’. The meaning of 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 20.13 (126v5 KT 1.58) is not in doubt. It corresponds closely to Sanskrit 【tädana-】 and Tibetan 【rdeg-pa】 (see Bailey s. v. 【dvya-】). What reason is there for separating 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 23.17 from 【dvā̜ñä】 in Si 20.13 ? The absence of 【-y-】 is hardly significant. The 【-y-】 may be secondary in any case (see SGS 44 s. v. *【dav-】), Even if it is not second_x005f_x001f_ary, 【dvā̜ñä】 could easily have been simplified to 【dvyā̜ñä】, In Ch ii.002 it could well be a defective writing of 【dvyā̜ñä】 since such defective spellings abound in that manuscript.|||Si 23.17 concerns the well-known 【śata-dhauta-ghṛta】, Its preparation is not explained in the Sanskrit text, but the Tibetan and Khotanese versions have more detail. Bailey quotes only part of the corresponding Tibetan, which has: 【yaṅ-na mar gźu-źiṅ hkhyag-tu bcug-pa de-lta-bur lan brgyahi bar-du byas-te rul-bar gyur-pahi naṅ-du śiṅ-mṅar-gyi phye-ma śas cher blug-ste sbyar-bas bsku-bar byaho】 ‘alternatively (【vā】), one must beat (【dhautaṃ】) ghee (【sarpir】) and make it congeal, and making it like that a hundred (【śata-】) times, when it has become rancid, one must pour into it in large quantity (【-utkaṭam】) the powder from liquorice (【yaṣṭi- madhu-】), and smear it (over the patient) (【lepanaṃ】)。|||It looks as though the Tibetan rendering provides an interpretation of 【dhauta-】 as ‘beaten’. It is clear that the Khotanese follows the Tibetan in this interpretation and that 【dvā̜ñä】 ‘to be beaten’ corresponds to Tibetan 【gźu-ba】 ‘to strike, to lash’ (Jäschke). 【gźu-ba】 is explained as 【brgyab-pa】 (‘to beat, strike’) by Sumatiratna.|||śata-dhauta-ghṛta in Vāgbhaṭa, Ah., Ci, 18.13 is correctly rendered in Tibetan by 【lan brgyar bkrus-pahi mar 】(Peking 196b4) ‘ghee that has been washed a hundred times’. It is washed with cold water (see VŚS s. v. 【śata-dhauta-ghrtam】; 【Śrīkaṇṭhadatta】 on Vṛ 19.1). It is no doubt beaten up with the cold water rather than ‘besmeared’ with it.  [Emmerik, I, 59]

DKS: (BS dvandva-?), K 109-315 cu nai by(e)ha dvada nai dharma ‘who does not get duality, not dharma_x001F_doctrine’; K 109-312-3 ttye sai durśīla dvade nai adv ay a vasve parāhq ‘of him even evil-moraled duality, not pure non-duality’.

SGS: ‘to make a noise (of animals)’ I b act. intr. A/B|||3 pl. pres, act., O.Kh.: 【najsīndi】 Z 2. 46; 【najsīndä】 Z 20. 30.|||Et. ? Base *nag/k-. H. W. B. points to Toch. A nāk-, B nā̌k- ‘to reproach’. [p.48]

SVK: In Diet. s.v. 【naṃñä】 Bailey quotes from P 2026 #99 【sumīrä śaśvāṃ naṃñä ttrāyi hatcä tcauryau dvīpyau】, which he translates ‘Sumeru (mountain) (and) the mustard seed he carries away to nothingness to_x001F_gether with the four continents’. His word 【naṃñä】, invented exclusively for this passage, he explains as deriving ‘from 【na-】 “not”, with 【-ṃña-】.|||The interpretation Bailey proposes for this passage does not agree with Buddhist teaching elsewhere. The correct interpretation was already given by me in 【JRAS】, 1967, 25: 【sumīrä śaśvā̜nąñä ttrāyi hatcä tcauryau dvīpyau】 ‘he will deliver Sumeru into the grain of mustard together with the four 【dvīpas】’ With this compare the similar formulation in Ch 1.0021b, a #38-39 【KBT】 151: 【sumīra garä pūsą. ttrāyau śaśvāṃ myā̜ñä bīśī hā baiśnä hatsa tcauryā dvīpyau】 ‘I will completely deliver Mount Sumeru into the middle of a grain of mustard, all of it utterly, together with the four 【dvīpas】’ The loc. sg. 【śaśvā̜nñä】 from 【śśaśvāna-】 ‘mustard grain’ is like 【padānaña】 loc. sg. from 【padāna-】 ‘vessel’ (SGS 262). [Emmerick, III, p.79]
